questions.text: What is the likely vector for the disease in a patient from Uttar Pradesh who presented with symptoms of fever, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, peripheral smear examination showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sandfly

Explanation:

  • The patient described with symptoms like fever, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and a peripheral smear showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast is most likely infected with Leishmania species, which cause visceral leishmaniasis (also known as Kala-azar). The organism observed in the smear (with a kinetoplast) is characteristic of Leishmania amastigotes.
  • Sandflies are the vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania species, including Leishmania donovani, which is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis in India, including Uttar Pradesh.

Life Cycle of Leishmania donovani

  1. Infection of the Vector:
    • A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus, Lutzomyia) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes.
  2. Development in the Sandfly:
    • Inside the sandfly’s midgut, amastigotes transform into promastigotes, which multiply and migrate to the proboscis.
  3. Transmission to the Mammalian Host:
    • When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes.
  4. Transformation in the Host:
    • Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes, which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly.
  5. Replication and Dissemination:
    • Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages.
  6. Transmission Back to the Sandfly:
    • If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues.

 

 

 

Clinical features of kala-azar:

  • Onset: Insidious.
  • The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous.
  • Night sweats
  • Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender.
  • Hepatomegaly is moderate.
  • Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent.
  • Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar).
  • The hair becomes thin and brittle.
  • Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen.
  • Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Ascites and edema may occur due to hypoalbuminemia.
  • Renal involvement is also common.
  • In the late stage of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, VL can present as an opportunistic infection. HIV coinfection rate is 5% in India and 20% in African countries.
  • Secondary infections such as herpes, measles, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and bacillary dysentery may occur.
  • Most untreated patients die in about two years due to some intercurrent disease such as dysentery, diarrhoea and tuberculosis.

 

Child with visceral leishmaniasis with hepatosplenomegaly

Diseases caused by Sandflies:

  • Leishmania
  • Sandfly fever caused by the Toscano virus
  • Bunya virus causing ‘Three-day fever’

Incorrect Options:

Tse-Tse fly (Option B): The Tse-Tse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma species, such as Trypanosoma brucei, which causes sleeping sickness (trypanosomiasis), not Leishmania.

Triatomine bug (Option C): This is the vector for Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease.

Female anopheles mosquito (Option D): This mosquito transmits Plasmodium species, the causative agents of malaria, but not Leishmania.

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Echinococcus granulosus

Explanation:

  • Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver (most common) and lungs.
  • The cysts have a fluid-filled, multilayered wall and may show a "water lily" sign if ruptured.
  • Humans are accidental hosts, acquiring infection through ingestion of eggs from dog feces.

 

Echinococcus granulosus:

 

Other name

Dog tapeworm

Definitive Host

Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox

Intermediate Host

Sheep and cattle

Accidental Intermediate Host

Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form)

Infective Form

Embryonated egg

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the eggs due to:

  • Intimate handling of infected dogs
  • Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces

Eggs

  • Ovoid in shape and brown in color
  • Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets

Larva

Represent structure of scolex of adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body.

Adult Worm
  • Consist of scolex, a short neck and strobila
  • Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets.

 

Life Cycle:

 

Schistosoma japonicum (Option B): This trematode causes intestinal and hepatosplenic schistosomiasis, leading to periportal fibrosis (Symmer’s pipestem fibrosis) and portal hypertension. It does not form cystic lesions.

Echinococcus multilocularis (Option C): This species causes alveolar echinococcosis, a more aggressive form resembling malignant hepatic infiltration rather than a well-defined cystic lesion.

Schistosoma mansoni (Option D): It causes hepatic schistosomiasis, characterized by eggs in the liver leading to granulomatous inflammation, but does not produce cystic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following option is wrong about Ascaris lumbricoides?

choices.text: Unembryonated fertilized egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil.

questions.solution:
Ascaris lumbricoides does not cause recital prolapse.

 

Life Cycle of Ascaris
  • Host: Humans only.
  • Infective Form: Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.
  • Transmission: Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water. (Option C)

 

Life Cycle Phases

Migratory Phase
  • L2 larvae hatch, molt to L3, penetrate the intestine and travel to the lungs via the heart.
  • In the lungs, they molt to L4, migrate to the pharynx, and are swallowed back into the intestine.

Intestinal Phase
  • L4 larvae become adult worms in the small intestine.
  • Females lay fertilized eggs in feces; unfertilized eggs may also be laid.

Development in Soil
  • Fertilized eggs become infective embryonated (L2 larvae) in 2 weeks under suitable conditions.
  • Unfertilized eggs disintegrate and are non-infective.
  • Embryonated eggs can survive for up to 15 years due to a thick eggshell and ascaroside, a resistant lipoprotein.

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features
  • Caused by the host immune response, larval migration, adult worm obstruction, and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Incubation: 60–70 days.
 

Pulmonary Phase
  • Symptoms appear within two weeks post-ingestion: cough, chest discomfort, and fever.
  • Severe cases may lead to Loeffler’s syndrome, characterized by eosinophilic pneumonia and transient lung infiltrates.
 

Intestinal Phase
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but malnutrition and growth retardation can occur, particularly in children <5 years.
  • Complications include intestinal obstruction, perforation, intussusception, or volvulus in older children.

Extraintestinal Complications

Larger worms may obstruct the biliary tree, causing biliary colic or pancreatitis.

Allergic Reactions

Reactions such as fever, urticaria, angioedema, and conjunctivitis may arise due to toxins released by adult worms.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective organs of locomotion:


	
		
			
			Parasite
			
			
			Organ of Locomotion
			
		
		
			
			1. Balamuthia mandrillaris
			
			
			a. Flagella
			
		
		
			
			2. Balantidium coli
			
			
			b. Cilia
			
		
		
			
			3. Trichomonas vaginalis
			
			
			c. Pseudopod
			
		
		
			
			4. Toxoplasma gondii
			
			
			d. No particular organ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

Balamuthia mandrillaris → Pseudopods

  • Free-living amoeba causing granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE).
  • Moves using pseudopods (temporary cytoplasmic projections).

Balantidium coli → Cilia

  • The only ciliated protozoan pathogenic to humans.
  • Causes balantidiasis (dysentery-like illness), often acquired from pigs.

Trichomonas vaginalis → Flagella

  • Pear-shaped protozoan with multiple flagella, responsible for trichomoniasis (STD).
  • No cyst stage (exists only in trophozoite form).

Toxoplasma gondii → No particular organ

  • An intracellular protozoan that moves via gliding motility (not a specific organ).
  • Causes toxoplasmosis, important in immunocompromised patients and pregnancy.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective intermediate hosts:


	
		
			
			Parasite
			
			
			Host
			
		
		
			
			1. Diphyllobothrium
			
			
			a. Sheep
			
		
		
			
			2. Paragonimus
			
			
			b. Crab
			
		
		
			
			3. Brugia
			
			
			c. Cyclops
			
		
		
			
			4. Fasciola
			
			
			d. Mosquitoes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

Explanation:

Diphyllobothrium (Fish Tapeworm) → Cyclops

  • The first intermediate host is Cyclops (Copepod, a freshwater crustacean).
  • The second intermediate host is freshwater fish.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming undercooked freshwater fish.

Paragonimus (Lung Fluke) → Crab

  • The first intermediate host is snail.
  • The second intermediate host is crabs or crayfish.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming raw or undercooked crabs.

Brugia (Causes Lymphatic Filariasis) → Mosquitoes

  • Brugia malayi & Brugia timori are transmitted by mosquitoes (Mansonia, Anopheles, Aedes).
  • The mosquito serves as the intermediate host and vector.

Fasciola (Liver Fluke) → Sheep

  • The definitive host is sheep, cattle, or humans.
  • The intermediate host is aquatic snails.
  • Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated aquatic plants like watercress.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved in its transmission.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trombiculid mite

Explanation:

  • Trombiculid mites (chigger mites) are the vectors for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Incorrect Options:

Hard tick (Option A): Hard ticks (Ixodidae) are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi), babesiosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. However, they are not the primary vectors for organisms transmitted by trombiculid mites.

Soft tick (Option B): Soft ticks (Argasidae) primarily transmit Borrelia species responsible for tick-borne relapsing fever. They do not play a role in the transmission of pathogens associated with trombiculid mites.

Louse (Option D): Lice are involved in transmitting Rickettsia prowazekii (epidemic typhus), Bartonella quintana (trench fever), and Borrelia recurrentis (louse-borne relapsing fever), but they are not involved in the transmission of scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, and CT head reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. What is the correct management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continue antiepileptics

Explanation:

  • Multiple calcified parenchymal cysts on CT head are characteristic of Neurocysticercosis (NCC) in the inactive (calcified) stage.
  • Seizures in calcified NCC are caused by gliotic scarring rather than active infection, so the primary treatment is antiepileptic therapy.
  • Antiparasitic drugs (Albendazole, Praziquantel) are ineffective in the calcified stage and can worsen inflammation.
  • Steroids are used only if perilesional edema is present, but they do not alter the course of calcified cysts.
  • The combination of albendazole and praziquantel is recommended for effective treatment of multiple viable cysts (>2 cysts).

Treatment of Neurocysticercosis

  1. Seizure Management: Anticonvulsant therapy is initiated upon seizure presentation. Stop if follow-up imaging shows resolution and no seizures for 24 months.
  2. Anthelmintic Therapy: Depends on the lesion stage.
  3. Cystic Lesions Treatment:
    • Albendazole: Drug of choice for parenchymal Neurocysticercosis (15 mg/kg daily for 10-14 days). Recommended for 1-2 parenchymal cysts.
    • Praziquantel: Alternative option (50 mg/kg in 3 divided doses daily for 10 days).
    • Albendazole + Praziquantel: For >2 viable cysts (Praziquantel: 50 mg/kg/day for 10-14 days).
    • Prednisolone: 10 mg three times daily for 14 days, starting 1 day before Albendazole or Praziquantel. Given to suppress the inflammation during the natural course of the disease.
  4. Stages of Cysts:
    • Viable Cysts: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Vesicular & Colloidal Stages: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Granulonodular Stage: Some experts recommend treatment.
    • Calcified Lesions: Do not require treatment with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Small, Solitary Cerebral Cysts: Often resolve without treatment.
  5. Operative Intervention: Indicated for hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having a nocturnal cough for the last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strongylodes stercoralis

Explanation:

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode that can cause strongyloidiasis. It is known to produce larvae that can be detected in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen. The patient's history of chronic steroid use is significant, as steroids can lead to immunosuppression, which in turn can lead to dissemination of Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis typically causes a chronic, indolent infection, which can worsen during immunosuppression or steroid therapy. This can lead to dissemination, causing symptoms like respiratory distress and eosinophilia, which are consistent with the patient's presentation of acute worsening of respiratory symptoms, nocturnal cough, and elevated eosinophils.
  • Strongyloidiasis can involve the lungs as larvae migrate through the lungs before being coughed up and swallowed, which explains the respiratory symptoms.

Rhabditiform larva

Filariform larva

1st stage of the larva (L1).

3d stage of the larva (L3).

Formed when eggs hatch in the small intestine.

Developed from two molts of the L1 larva.

Measures approximately 0.25 mm in length with a short muscul’ar double-bulb esophagus.

Measures about 0.55 mm in length, characterized by a long, slender shape, uniform esophagus & notched tail.

Found in feces.

Seen in hyperinfection & disseminated infection may show in sputum, stool and body fluids.

Diagnostic form

Infective form

 

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis Infection

Effect of Migrating Larvae
  • Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic.
  • Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs.
  • Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour.
  • Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease.

Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae
  • Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss.
  • Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Hyperinfection Syndrome
  • Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae.
  • Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection.
  • Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Disseminated Strongyloidiasis
  • Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis.
  • Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases.
  • Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment.



 

Laboratory Diagnosis

Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis.

Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases.

Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae.

Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections.

Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides.

Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes.

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection.
  • Ivermectin (200 mg/kg daily for 2 days)

Incorrect Options:

Ancylostoma caninum (Option A): This is a hookworm primarily affecting dogs, though it can occasionally infect humans through contact with contaminated soil. However, it is less likely to cause eosinophilic pneumonia or produce larvae detectable in a BAL specimen.

Capillaria philippinensis (Option B): This parasite is responsible for intestinal capillariasis, primarily affecting the intestines and causing symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain, rather than causing respiratory symptoms or eosinophilia associated with respiratory issues. It does not typically involve larvae in the BAL.

Enterobius vermicularis (Option D): This is the cause of pinworm infections, which are generally not associated with eosinophilia or respiratory symptoms. The larvae of Enterobius vermicularis do not typically appear in BAL specimens, as it is primarily an intestinal parasite.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wuchereria bancrofti

Explanation:

  • The parasite given is Wuchereria bancrofti, which is sheathed and has nuclei that do not extend to the tip of the tail.

Nuclei extend to the tip of the tail

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

Sheath

Sheathed

Unsheathed

Periodicity

Nocturnal

Nocturnal

Primary Vector

Culex, Anopheles, Aedes

Mansonia spp., Anopheles

Chrysops spp.

Simulium spp.

Culicoides

Brugia timori (Option C):

questions.text: A female patient from the northeastern part of the country presents with progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. Examination reveals proximal limb swelling more than distal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Night blood test for worms

Explanation:

  • The northeastern part of the country is endemic for lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi), which causes proximal limb lymphedema due to lymphatic obstruction.
  • Microfilariae exhibit nocturnal periodicity, making a night blood test the preferred initial investigation.

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
  • Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae

 

Life Cycle of Filaria (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi):

 

Lab Diagnosis:

1. Demonstration of Microfilaria:

  • In blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix or hydrocele fluid.
  • Best collect night blood samples between 10pm and 4 am.
  • Microfilaria can be seen in unstained as well as stained specimens.
  • Staining is performed using Giemsa, Leishman, or polychrome methylene blue.

 

Concentration Techniques: Done if microfilaria density is low

  • Knott’s concentration technique
  • Nucleopore filtration
  • Diethylcarbamazine provocation test (DCT):
    • Small dose of DEC given (2 mg/kg body weight)
    • Forces microfilaria to appear in peripheral blood during daytime.
  • Quantitative buffy coat

2. Ultrasonography:

  • Identify motile adult worms in the scrotum and female breast within dilated lymphatics, known as the "filaria dance sign."

3. Hemogram:

  • Eosinophilia
  • Elevated serum IgE levels

4. Demonstration of Antibody: Cannot distinguish between current and past infections.

5. Demonstration of Circulating Antigen:

  • Highly sensitive and specific
  • Trop-bio test: Semiquantitative sandwich ELISA
  • ELISA: To detect specific IgG4 antibody against W.bancrofti antigen (WbSXP-1)
  • Immunochromatographic test (ICT): Detects soluble W.bancrofti antigen using monoclonal antibody (AD12) in serum.

Treatment:

  • Drug of Choice: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC)
  • Mass drug therapy is given as either:
    • DEC alone
    • DEC + Albendazole
    • DEC + Ivermectin

 

Echocardiography (Option A): Cardiac conditions such as heart failure or superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome can cause limb swelling. However, these usually present with bilateral swelling and additional systemic symptoms. Given the patient's regional background and asymmetric proximal swelling, filariasis is a more likely cause.

Duplex venous scan of limbs (Option C): A venous scan is useful in detecting deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which typically causes distal rather than proximal limb swelling. In this case, lymphatic obstruction is a more likely cause.

ECG (Option D): Although the patient has a history of coronary artery disease, ECG does not evaluate limb swelling and is not the next best step in this scenario.

questions.text: A man with a fever of unknown origin has a job that requires traveling around the world. The histology of the bone marrow is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) rk39 antigen test

Explanation:

  • The given histology image of bone marrow picture histology reveals Leishman Donovan bodies, suggesting typical Leishmaniasis. Leishman Donovan bodies are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size

Diagnosis of Kala-azar :

  • Depends upon direct and indirect evidences:

 

 

CFT: Complement Fixation Test; CIEP: Counter Immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: Direct Agglutination Test; DNA: Deoxyribonucleic Acid; ELISA: Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay; ICT: Immunochromatographic Test; IFAT: Indirect Immunofluorescent Antibody Test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction; rK39: Recombinant Kinesin 39

Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

Materials collected:

1. Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows).

2. Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

3. Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

4. Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test (Option A): A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.
  • Liver biopsy is not a safe procedure and carries a risk of haemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

pLDH (Option B) Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) is a diagnostic test for malaria caused by Plasmodium species.

Galactose lectin antigen (Option C) is a diagnostic test for Entamoeba histolytica.

HRP-2 antigen (Option D) is a diagnostic criteria for malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: Which of the given statements accurately reflects the characteristics of trematodes?

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica is not acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

Explanation:

Fasciola Hepatica

  • Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction, and inflammatory reactions.

Morphology

Adult Fluke:

 

  • Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad.
  • Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width.
  • Color: Typically brown or grey.
  • Distinctive Features:
    • Cone-shaped anterior end.
    • Two suckers, an oral sucker at the front and a ventral sucker close to it, used for attachment to host tissues.
    • The fluke’s body is covered by a tegument (a protective outer layer) with spines aiding in attachment.

Eggs:

 

  • Size: Large, oval, and approximately 130-150 µm in length.
  • Color: Yellowish-brown.
  • Characteristics:
    • Each egg has an operculum (a lid-like structure) at one end, which opens to release the miracidium (the larval stage).
    • Eggs are unembryonated when passed out in feces.

Life Cycle

 

  1. Eggs in Water
    • Eggs are expelled in the feces of infected mammals (definitive hosts).
    • Under suitable environmental conditions, miracidia are released from eggs after 9–15 days.
  2. Infection of Snails (Intermediate Host)
    • Miracidia penetrate specific freshwater snails, such as Lymnaea spp.
    • Inside the snail, they progress through stages: sporocyst, redia, and eventually cercaria.
  3. Release and Encystment
    • Cercariae exit the snail and encyst on aquatic vegetation, transforming into metacercariae, the infective stage.
  4. Infection of Mammals (Definitive Host)
    • Mammals, including humans, become infected by consuming contaminated water or vegetation with metacercariae.
    • In the duodenum, metacercariae excyst, penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate to the liver, and lodge in the bile ducts, maturing into adult flukes.

Clinical Presentation

Acute Phase (Invasive or Hepatic Stage):

  • Duration: Begins about 2-3 weeks post-infection and may last for several months.
  • Symptoms:
    • Fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
    • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and occasionally jaundice.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
    • Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil count in blood).

Chronic Phase (Biliary Stage):

  • Duration: Occurs months to years post-infection.
  • Symptoms:
    • Biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, and cholangitis (inflammation of the bile ducts).
    • Gallbladder symptoms, liver abscesses, and secondary bacterial infections in severe cases.
    • Possible fibrosis of the bile ducts with prolonged infection.

Investigations

  1. Serology:
    • ELISA for detection of anti-Fasciola antibodies (sensitive in both acute and chronic infections).
    • Immunoblotting can also confirm the diagnosis.
  2. Stool Examination:
    • Microscopic detection of eggs in stool samples; however, eggs are typically not present in the acute phase and may be difficult to detect in chronic cases.
  3. Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Useful in detecting hepatobiliary abnormalities such as bile duct dilation or liver abscesses.
    • CT/MRI: May show liver lesions or track the migration of larvae in the liver.
  4. Blood Tests:
    • Eosinophilia is common in the acute phase.
    • Liver function tests: Elevated liver enzymes, especially in chronic disease.

Management

Antiparasitic Treatment:

  • Triclabendazole: The drug of choice, effective against both adult and larval stages. Dosage: Oral dose of 10-12 mg/kg, with a repeat dose after 12 hours if needed.

Alternative Medications:

  • Bithionol: Sometimes used if triclabendazole is unavailable.

Incorrect Options:

Schistosoma are Monoecious (Option B) Schistosoma is dioecious, i.e., males and females are separate.

Fasciola Hepatica is not acquired through Contaminated Water (Option C) Fasciola hepatica is primarily acquired through ingestion of contaminated water or food that contains metacercariae, the infective stage of the fluke.

Triclabendazole is the Treatment of Choice for all Trematode Infections (Option D) While triclabendazole is an effective treatment for Fasciola hepatica infections, it is not the treatment of choice for all trematode infections. Other medications, such as praziquantel, are commonly used for the treatment of various trematode infections, including schistosomiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae

questions.solution:
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue: This is a xenodiagnostic method. It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis.

Xenodiagnosis:

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic technique in which live vectors or organisms are used to detect the presence of an infectious agent in a host. This is particularly useful for detecting pathogens that are difficult to isolate or grow in a laboratory setting.

 

Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC (Option A) This method involves introducing a loop of rabbit ileum (part of the small intestine) into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract and assessing the effects of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) on the loop.

Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis (Option C) It involves injecting a hamster with a biopsy specimen from the spleen to diagnose leishmaniasis. The hamster serves as a host for the parasite, but it is not a different species used for diagnosis.

Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria (Option D) It involves conducting an intradermal test on guinea pigs to assess the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The guinea pigs are used as a model to evaluate the effects of the toxin, but they are not a different species used for diagnosis.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.
questions.solution:
• In the given information where the formol-ether sedimentation technique is mentioned and level D is labeled at the base of the tube, it indicates that parasitic ova will be seen at this level when viewed under a microscope.
  • Formol-ether sedimentation is a commonly used technique for concentrating parasites and ova from stool samples when the egg burden is low. In this technique, the stool sample is mixed with a formalin-ether solution. The high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water, the eggs sinks to the bottom. Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution.
  • The different levels represented by markings are:
  • Level 1: represents the topmost layer of the sample and typically contains ether.
  • Level II: contain some debris.
  • Level III: contains formalin.
  • Level IV: protozoan cyst and eggs.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image
questions.solution:
Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology
 

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end (Option C) & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Stongyloides Stercoralis (Option A) The female worm is thin, transparent and the male worm is shorter and broader than the female.

Enterobius Vermicularis (Option B) is known as Pinworm. The adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread and the female worm is 8-13 mm long and 0.3-0.5 mm thick, its posterior third is drawn into a thin pointed pin-like tail.

Ancylostoma Duodenale (Option C) They are known as hookworms. The male worm is smaller than the female worm. The posterior end of the male is expanded into a copulatory bursa, which consists of three lobes. The female worm is larger. Its hind end is conoid, with a subterminal anus situated ventrally.

questions.text: Based on the given image, which of the following specimens would not contain filarial worms, considering the presented disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Saliva

Explanation:

The given image is of lymphedema of left leg seen in lymphatic filariasis aka elephantiasis occurs as a result of chronic infection of filariasis, due to lymphatic obstruction ultimately leading to swelling of the limbs. Filarial worms can be found in blood, urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, but not in saliva.

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
  • Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae.

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

DEC provocation test:
  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour
  • Microfilariae can appear in the daytime.
  • Highest specificity

5.

Serological tests
  • Cannot differentiate between past and present infection

6.

Mass blood survey
  • Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

questions.text: What is the underlying cause of the symptoms exhibited by a 55-year-old male, including fever, fatigue, and abnormal vital signs, along with the identification of the causative agent based on the microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Plasmodium falciparum:

Explanation:

  • Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of severe malaria, which can present with symptoms like fever, fatigue, abnormal vital signs (such as hypotension or tachycardia), and in some cases, organ failure or cerebral malaria. It is the most dangerous of the Plasmodium species and can cause life-threatening complications, especially if not treated promptly.
  • The microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Vivax

Falciparum

Malariae

Enlarged

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Large (9-10 μm)

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium vivax (Option A): This species can cause milder malaria compared to P. falciparum. The blood smear for P. vivax often shows larger trophozoites with a larger, irregular-shaped ring and sometimes a "schuffner's dots" characteristic, which isn't described in the scenario.

Plasmodium ovale (Option C): This species is similar to P. vivax in causing mild malaria. It tends to have oval-shaped red blood cells in the smear and may also show schuffner's dots. It is less likely to cause the severe symptoms described.

Plasmodium malariae (Option D): This species generally causes milder malaria and may present with quotidian fever (fever occurring every 24 hours). The blood smear shows band forms or Ziemann’s dots, which are not typically associated with the severe symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: All are correct about toxoplasma gondii except:

choices.text: Infection is more common in third trimester than in first trimester
Can be cultured in peritoneal cavity of mice

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oocysts in stool are infective

Explanation:

  • The freshly passed oocyst of Toxoplasma is not infectious. They undergo sporulation in the soil with formation of two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites. The sporulated oocyst is infective.

Toxoplasma gondii

Host (Option B)
  • Definitive host: Cat and other cat species (family Felidae)
  • Intermediate host: Humans and animals like sheep, rodents, pigs etc

Infective stages
  • Sporulated oocyst
  • Tachyzoites
  • Bradyzoites (tissue cyst)

Modes of transmission

Infective form

Blood Transfusion

 

Tachyzoites

Mother to child

Undercooked or raw meat

Sporulated Oocyst

Ingestion of contaminated products

Bradyzoites

 

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission.

  • As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

Pre-pregnancy

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)

 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission. (Option A)
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

 

Diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis

Antenatal

USG

  • Done at 20-24 weeks of gestation and repeated every 2-4 weeks
  • It helps detect lesions of congenital infection, such as
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Ascites

Serology

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) or IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay) is done using maternal serum to detect IgM and IgG

PCR
  • Amniotic fluid can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA, which can confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not done routinely as it is invasive and expensive, and other safer options are available.

Postnatal diagnosis

Serology

Newborn Sera and maternal sera are both used to detect

  • IgG >= 1000: Possible infection
  • IgM >= 1:4 after 2 weeks of age: Indicates probable diagnosis
  • IgA: Disappears within 10 days of birth; thus, persistence indicates postnatal infection

Sabin-Feldman test - Complement fixation test

Other tests

  • Animal inoculation (no longer done for clinical diagnosis) (Option D)
  • Skin test of Frenkel
  • Microscopy of samples to detect tachyzoites using Giemsa or PAS

questions.text:
Which protozoans have two morphologic forms?


	Naegleria fowleri
	Acanthamoeba
	Trichomonas
	Giardia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2,4

Explanation:

Naegleria fowleri, Acanthamoeba, and Giardia have two morphologic forms.

Naegleria fowleri:

Naegleria is a free-living amoeba commonly found in warm freshwater environments. In nature, it exists in two forms: cysts and trophozoites.

  • Cyst: Round
  • Trophozoite: Can occur in two forms – amoeboid and flagellated forms.

Life cycle:

  • Infective form: Trophozoite.
  • Mode of transmission: Nasal contamination occurs during swimming in fresh, hot water bodies like ponds, rivers, swimming pools, or lakes.
  • CNS invasion: Invades nasal mucosa → Cribriform plate → Olfactory nerve → Brain → Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis.

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites.
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes:
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.

Trophozoite

Cyst

  • Show spikes (Acantho - Spikes)

  • Double-walled, with an outer wrinkled cyst wall.

Giardia lamblia: The life cycle of Giardia lamblia involves ingestion of cysts from contaminated food or water. These cysts transform into trophozoites in the small intestine, multiply, and eventually form new cysts that are excreted in the feces to infect new hosts. This causes giardiasis.

Trichomoniasis (Option 3) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, and it does not have two different morphological forms. It typically presents with the frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a foul odour, along with vaginal itching and discomfort during urination. The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

questions.text: A patient presents with peripheral pruritis, especially at night. A scotch tape test reveals characteristic eggs. What is the most likely organism identified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enterobius vermicularis

Explanation:

The image of the eggs, combined with perianal itching that worsens at night, is characteristic of an Enterobius vermicularis (Pinworm/Threadworm) infection.

Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group are school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm

 
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

 

 
  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm

 
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

 
  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

Life cycle

Scotch-tape test:

A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.

Hookworms (Option C), including Ancylostoma duodenale (Option B) and Necator americanus, infect through skin penetration and migrate to the intestines, where they feed on blood and may cause iron-deficiency anemia. They do not cause perianal itching, and their eggs are diagnosed via stool examination, not the scotch tape test

Hymenolepsis nana (Option D) infects the human intestine through ingestion of contaminated food or water. It can cause mild gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal discomfort or diarrhea, but perianal itching is not a typical symptom. Eggs are diagnosed via stool microscopy, and the scotch tape test is not used for its detection.

questions.text:
Which of the following helminth is known to show autoinfection?


	H. nana
	Ascaris lumbricoides
	Ancylostoma duodenale
	Strongyloides stercoralis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 4

Explanation:

Among the given options, Hymenolepis nana and Strongyloides stercoralis shows Autoinfection.

  • Few intestinal parasites may infect the same person by contaminated hand (external autoinfection) or by reverse peristalsis (internal autoinfection).
  • Parasites that show Autoinfection in humans
    • Strongyloides stercoralis (Statement 4)
    • Enterobius vermicularis
    • Toxocara
    • Giardia lamblia
    • Ascaris lumbricoides
    • Schistosoma mansoni
    • Cryptosporidium spp.
    • Hymenolepis nana (Statement 1)

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option B) is a large roundworm that requires its eggs to develop in soil before becoming infective. Since it depends on external environmental conditions for development, it does not exhibit autoinfection.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option C), a hookworm, requires external development in soil. The larvae infect humans by penetrating the skin, and like Ascaris, it does not undergo autoinfection within the host.

questions.text: Malarial control means :

choices.text: To reduce the disease so that it is not public health problem
To reduce the mortality to zero
To prevent local transmission for 3 days

questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A

  • Malarial control means to reduce the disease so that it is not a public health problem.
  • Malarial control refers to the efforts and strategies aimed at reducing the burden of malaria and its impact on public health. The ultimate goal of malarial control is to eliminate malaria as a public health problem. This involves reducing the number of malaria cases to a level where it no longer poses a significant threat to the population.

Incorrect options:

Option B. "To reduce the mortality to zero," focuses specifically on reducing the number of deaths caused by malaria. While reducing malaria-related mortality is an important aspect of malarial control, it does not encompass the entirety of the control measures. C.

Option C. "To prevent local transmission for 3 days," is a limited objective and does not encompass the broader goal of malarial control. Malaria control efforts aim to achieve sustained and long-term reductions in transmission, not just for a short period of time. D.

Option D. "To reduce indices to zero," is not a comprehensive description of malarial control. Malarial vector indices, such as mosquito density and parasite prevalence, are important indicators used to monitor and guide control efforts, but reducing these indices to zero may not always be achievable or necessary for effective control.

questions.text: Which of the following options encompasses the term "Malarial vector indices"?   	Human blood index 	Biting density 	Slide positivity rate 	Inoculation rate
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: B

  • B is the correct answer: 1 and 3 include "Malarial vector indices.
  • Malarial vector indices are parameters used to assess the transmission intensity and risk of malaria in a specific area. They provide information about the behaviour and abundance of mosquito vectors and their potential to transmit the malaria parasite.
  • Human blood index: The human blood index is a measure of the proportion of blood meals taken by mosquitoes from humans. It indicates the preference of mosquitoes to feed on humans, which is crucial for malaria transmission.
  • Slide positivity rate: The slide positivity rate is the percentage of blood slides examined under a microscope that show the presence of malaria parasites. It is an indicator of the prevalence of malaria infections in the population and reflects the intensity of transmission.

Incorrect options:

Option A.  is incorrect because it includes all four options, but only options 1 and 3 are considered as malarial vector indices.

Option C. is incorrect because it includes options 2 and 4, but neither of them is considered as a malarial vector index.

Option D.  is incorrect because it includes options 1, 2, and 4, but option 2 is not considered as a malarial vector index.

questions.text: Identify the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Ancylostoma braziliense

  • The given organism is Ancylostoma braziliense
  • Cutaneous larva migrans, is caused by the larvae of Ancylostoma braziliense.
  • Ancylostoma braziliense is a hookworm that primarily infects dogs and cats.
  • The larvae of this parasite can penetrate the human skin, usually through direct contact with contaminated soil or sand.
  • Once in the skin, the larvae migrate and cause an inflammatory reaction, resulting in the characteristic serpiginous tracks seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method ?

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue:

  • In the Xenodiagnostic method, arthropod vectors are fed on infected patients for 2-4 weeks, after which the vectors are examined for parasite presence.
  • It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: It is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria.

Option C - Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as the vector for leishmaniasis is sandfly.

Option D - Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector, and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ascaris lumbricoides

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides. The female Ascaris lumbricoides is identified by a straight conical posterior end & a vulvar groove, distinguishing it from the male, which has a ventrally curved posterior end. Females are also larger, measuring 20-40 cm, compared to males at 15-30 cm

Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Incorrect Options:

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option A): This nematode is much smaller and thread-like. It primarily affects the small intestine and is diagnosed via larvae in stool rather than large adult worms. It can cause autoinfection, leading to hyperinfection syndrome in immunocompromised individuals.

Enterobius vermicularis (Option B): Also known as the pinworm, it is much smaller (~1 cm) and resides in the perianal region. It causes perianal itching (especially at night), and diagnosis is confirmed using the Scotch tape test to detect eggs.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option C): This is a hookworm, characterized by its curved morphology and cutting plates/teeth. It causes iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss in the intestines. Infection occurs via skin penetration from contaminated soil.

questions.text: Which organism is the cause of perianal itching in a child who experiences symptoms primarily at night, leading to sleep disturbances? The eggs of the responsible organism can be observed in the accompanying image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Enterobius vermicularis

Explanation:

  • The parasite infestation in the given scenario is of Enterobius vermicularis or the pinworm which causes intense itching in the perianal region due to the female worm laying eggs in this region at night. The infective stage of this is the embryonated egg. The eggs are often observed on the perianal skin, and when the child scratches the area, they can spread the eggs to others or other surfaces. The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained

Enterobius vermicularis / Pinworm / Threadworm

Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group being school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm

 
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

 
  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

 
  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

Scotch-tape test:

  • A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.

Life cycle:

  • Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans.
  • It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration.
  • The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults.
  • The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the feces.
  • The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all eggs or gets crushed due to scratching.

 

Pathogenicity:

  • The embryonated egg is the infective form.
  • The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults.
  • It affects females > males.
  • The infection occurs in two ways:
    • Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by nails after scratching the region.
    • Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin.

Incorrect Options:

Trichuris trichiura (Option B) (whipworm): While whipworms can infect the intestines, they are not typically associated with perianal itching or the nocturnal symptoms described. Their main symptoms involve abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally rectal prolapse.

Trichinella spiralis (Option C): This parasite causes trichinosis, which is typically associated with consuming undercooked pork or wild game. The primary symptoms are muscle pain and swelling, not perianal itching.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option D): This parasite causes strongyloidiasis, which typically presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, diarrhea, and skin rashes, but not specifically with perianal itching.

questions.text: A 55 year old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile at 40 degree C, hypotensive, and has tachycardia. The blood smear of this patient is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

Based on the description of the patient's symptoms (fever, hypotension, tachycardia) and the blood smear findings, Plasmodium falciparum is the most likely causative agent. P. falciparum is known to cause severe malaria, which can present with high fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and other complications like cerebral malaria and organ dysfunction. The Microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

Plasmodium vivax (Option A): This species can cause milder malaria compared to P. falciparum. The blood smear for P. vivax often shows larger trophozoites with a larger, irregular-shaped ring and sometimes a "schuffner's dots" characteristic, which isn't described in the scenario.

Plasmodium ovale (Option C): This species is similar to P. vivax in causing mild malaria. It tends to have oval-shaped red blood cells in the smear and may also show schuffner's dots. It is less likely to cause the severe symptoms described.


Plasmodium malariae (Option D): This species generally causes milder malaria and may present with quotidian fever (fever occurring every 24 hours). The blood smear shows band forms or Ziemann’s dots, which are not typically associated with the severe symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: What is the average incubation period of plasmodium falciparum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12

Explanation:

  • For Plasmodium falciparum, the average incubation period is typically around 12 days from the time of infection until the onset of symptoms.
  • The parasite binds to RBCs using the Basigin receptor (CD147), facilitating its entry into the cells.

Prepatent period: The time from the entry of the parasite into the host until it is detectable in peripheral blood.

Incubation period: Time interval from the entry of the parasite until the appearance of the first clinical symptoms.

Receptors on RBC:

  • Plasmodium vivax: Binds to Duffy antigen (also known as Duffy blood group antigen) on the surface of red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Plasmodium falciparum: Binds to Basigin (also known as CD147), a protein expressed on the surface of RBCs

Options B, C, & D are incorrect.

questions.text:
The egg shown below belongs to?

 ​​ ​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Whipworm

Explanation:

Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) eggs are barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs (mucoid plugs at both ends) as shown in the image.

Trichuris trichiura / Whip worm

Morphology

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

Pathogenicity:

  • The incubation period is 70 to 90 days.
  • Transmission:
    • The infective stage is the embryonated eggs, which carry the rhabditiform larvae
    • The mode of transmission is by contaminated food or water.
    • The swallowed eggs hatch into larvae in the small intestine.
    • Adult female worms live in the cecum and lay eggs that are excreted in the feces.

The life cycle of Trichuris trichiura:

  • Man is the only natural host for T.trichiura and the egg develops in the soil.
  • There is no intermediate host.

Clinical features:

  • Generally asymptomatic unless the worm load is heavy.
  • Potential issues arise from mechanical effects or allergic reactions.
  • Abdominal pain and anorexia.
  • Trichuris dysentery syndrome: bloody or mucoid.
  • Iron deficiency anemia: due to blood loss.
  • Recurrent rectal prolapse: due to heavy worm load in the rectum.
  • Malnutrition causes growth retardation.
  • Cognitive impairment: due to inflammatory cytokines induced by Trichuris species.

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Stool Examination:
    • Conducted through direct wet mount or stool concentration methods.
    • A single stool specimen is typically sufficient for diagnosing symptomatic cases due to high egg output.
    • Egg characteristics:
      • Measure approximately 50 × 22 µm.
      • Barrel-shaped with mucus plugs at both ends.
      • Bile-stained and capable of floating in a saturated salt solution.
  • Adult worm characteristics:
    • Whip-shaped, measuring 3–5 cm long.
    • The anterior three-fifths is thin and coiled, resembling a rope, while the posterior two-fifths is short and thick.
  • Other findings:
    • Peripheral blood eosinophilia (typically less than 15%).
    • Increased serum IgE levels.
  • Colonoscopy:
    • The adult worms are seen attached to the mucosa, giving a characteristic “coconut cake rectum” appearance.

Management of trichuriasis:

  • Mebendazole:
    • 500 mg as a single dose
    • It is only moderately effective, with cure rates of 70-90%.
  • Albendazole:
    • 400 mg daily for three doses.
    • It is safe and effective.
  • Ivermectin:
    • 200 mg/kg daily for three doses.
    • It is safe but less effective.

Hookworm (Option A): Eggs are oval, thin-shelled, and segmented with a smooth surface.

Pinworm (Option C): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and asymmetrical with a thin shell.

Roundworm (Option D): Ascaris lumbricoides eggs have a thick, mammillated (bumpy) shell in their fertilized form.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female from a tribal area presents with fever for the last 3 days. A peripheral smear confirms the diagnosis of malaria. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

  • Plasmodium falciparum is the most common cause of malaria in tribal and endemic areas of India, particularly in regions with high transmission rates.
  • It causes severe malaria with complications such as cerebral malaria, renal failure, and severe anemia.
  • It is responsible for most fatal cases of malaria worldwide.
