questions.text: Which of the following causative agents is commonly transmitted by soil and is characterized by the egg in stool, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trichuris trichiura

Explanation:

  • Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) is a soil-transmitted helminth that infects humans via ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated soil.
  • The diagnostic feature is its characteristic barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs (seen in stool examination).
  • It causes trichuriasis, presenting with:
    • Chronic diarrhea
    • Iron deficiency anemia
    • Rectal prolapse (in severe cases, especially in children)

Trichuris trichiura / Whip worm

Morphology

 

 

 

 

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

 

 

 

 

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

 

 

 

 

 

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

 

Pathogenicity:

  • The incubation period is 70 to 90 days.
  • Transmission:
    • The infective stage is the embryonated eggs, which carry the rhabditiform larvae.
    • The mode of transmission is by contaminated food or water.
    • The swallowed eggs hatch into larvae in the small intestine.
    • Adult female worms live in the cecum and lay eggs that are excreted in the feces.

The life cycle of Trichuris trichiura:

  • Man is the only natural host for T.trichiura and the egg develops in the soil.
  • There is no intermediate host.

 

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option B): Hookworm that penetrates the skin (not ingested).

  • Causes iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss.
  • Eggs are oval with thin shells (not barrel-shaped).

Necator americanus (Option C) : Another hookworm with skin penetration transmission.

  • Causes ground itch, anemia, eosinophilia.
  • Eggs resemble those of Ancylostoma (thin-walled, oval).

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option D): Most common helminth worldwide.

  • Eggs are round with a thick, bumpy coat (not barrel-shaped).
  • Causes intestinal obstruction and Loeffler’s syndrome (lung migration).

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with chronic watery diarrhea. The histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

  • Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan parasite commonly associated with contaminated water sources.
  • It causes symptoms such as foul-smelling, greasy diarrhoea, bloating, and abdominal cramps.
  • Biopsy findings may reveal luminal organisms attached to the intestinal epithelium, causing blunting of the villi and inflammation without tissue invasion.
  • The characteristic appearance of Giardia trophozoites on biopsy is often described as resembling "falling leaves" due to their distinctive shape and attachment pattern.

 

Entamoeba histolytica (Option B): Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that can cause amoebic dysentery. Histological examination would typically show invasive trophozoites within the colonic mucosa, unlike the luminal organisms in this case.

 

Microsporidia (Option C): Causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS). Not typically seen in the duodenum; would show spore forms on histology, but not characteristic of the watery diarrhea here.

Cryptosporidia (Option D): Cryptosporidium is a protozoan parasite that can cause watery diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The organisms are typically small, round oocysts. However, the histological findings of luminal organisms without tissue invasion are more typical of Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a recent travel history to Africa presents with fever, confusion and neurological deficits. Laboratory analysis reveals the following findings. This organism exhibits a specific property that facilitates sequestration in vascular beds to avoid splenic clearance. What is the phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytoadherence

Explanation: The patient’s symptoms, including fever, confusion, and neurological deficits, along with the travel history to Africa, suggest a Plasmodium falciparum infection, which is the causative agent of severe malaria. Plasmodium falciparum has a specific property that facilitates its sequestration in the microvasculature, especially in organs like the brain (leading to cerebral malaria), by adhering to the endothelial cells of blood vessels. This process is known as cytoadherence.

Plasmodium falciparum is the primary species associated with cytoadherence, where infected red blood cells adhere to endothelial cells in blood vessels. This leads to complications like cerebral malaria due to vessel blockage and reduced blood flow.

Pathogenesis of Malignant Malaria:

Cytoadherence:

  • In Plasmodium falciparum malaria, late-stage schizonts secrete proteins that create knob-like protrusions on the surfaces of infected RBCs. This results in the expression of the adhesive protein PfEMP-1 (P. falciparum Erythrocyte Membrane Protein), which makes the infected RBCs sticky.
  • Inflammatory cytokines, particularly IFN-γ, enhance the expression of endothelial receptors such as thrombospondin, E-selectin, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in the brain, chondroitin sulfate B in the placenta, and CD36 in most other organs. These receptors promote the cytoadherence of infected

  • RBCs to the endothelium, leading to blockage of capillaries and venules.

Rosette formation: Infected RBCs can adhere to uninfected RBCs, forming rosettes.

Auto-Agglutination: The phenomenon where parasitised red blood cells (RBCs) clump together

These mechanisms cause capillary plugging and reduced microcirculation in vital organs, including the brain, kidneys, lungs, spleen, intestines, bone marrow, and placenta, resulting in severe complications like cerebral malaria.

Other notable virulence factors:

  • Histidine-rich protein II (HRP II)
  • Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)

Rosetting (Option A): This refers to the formation of clusters of uninfected red blood cells around an infected red blood cell. It is a phenomenon observed in Plasmodium falciparum infections, but cytoadherence is the more accurate term for the process responsible for sequestration in the microvasculature.

Agglutination (Option B): This refers to the clumping of cells or particles, typically used to describe antibody-antigen interactions. It is not related to the sequestration of parasitized red blood cells in malaria.

Schizogony (Option D): This is the asexual reproductive process of Plasmodium, during which the parasite undergoes multiple rounds of division inside red blood cells. It is a key part of the parasite's life cycle but does not describe the sequestration mechanism that causes the clinical manifestations seen in malaria.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are advantages of a saline mount compared to an iodine mount in stool microscopy?

1. Motility of trophozoites

2. Internal structure of cysts

3. Differentiate bile stained and non bile stained
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

Saline Mount (Normal Saline Wet Mount) - Advantages:

  • Motility of trophozoites (Statement 1) → Saline mount preserves the natural motility of protozoan trophozoites (e.g., Giardia lamblia shows "falling leaf" motility, Entamoeba histolytica shows directional motility).
  • Differentiation of bile-stained vs non-bile-stained ova (Statement 3) → Saline mount allows observation of color differences, making it useful to distinguish bile-stained ova (e.g., Ascaris lumbricoides fertilized eggs) from non-bile-stained ones.

Internal Structure of Cysts( Statement 3) → Iodine mount is better for cyst structures.

  • Iodine stains the glycogen and nuclei of protozoan cysts, improving visualization of internal structures (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia cysts). Saline mount does not enhance internal details well.

Stool sample processing

Microscopic examination of stool samples

This is done by two methods:

  • Direct wet mount examination
  • Permanent staining methods

Direct wet mount

Preparation:

  • Drops of saline and Lugol’s iodine are used on the left and right sides of the slide.
  • Mix ~2 mg of feces to form a smooth suspension.
  • Place a coverslip on the mount for examination under a microscope.

Observation:

  • Trophozoites
  • Normal constituents of stool like plant fibers and starch cells can be seen
  • Cellular Elements:
    • Pus cells (in inflammatory diarrhea)
    • Red blood cells (in dysentery)
  • Charcot-Leyden Crystals

 

 

Types of wet mounts:

Saline mount:

  • Uses: Detects trophozoites, cysts, helminth eggs, and larvae.
  • Advantages:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites and larvae.
    • Bile staining property can be assessed (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown).

Iodine mount:

  • Advantages: Better visualization of nuclear details in cysts, larvae, and eggs.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Iodine immobilizes and kills parasites, hindering motility observation.
    • Bile staining property cannot be assessed.

Permanent stained smears

 
  • This method stains the internal structures.
  • Purpose: For accurate detection of protozoan cysts and trophozoites.
  • Common Stains:
    • Iron-hematoxylin stain.
    • Trichrome stain.
    • Modified acid-fast stain for coccidian parasites (e.g., Cryptosporidium).

 

Sedimentation techniques and Flotation techniques are concentration techniques used to recover low numbers of parasites in stool samples.

  • Useful for epidemiological studies and assessing treatment response.
  • Detects eggs, cysts, and larvae but does not detect trophozoites, as these get destroyed in the process.
  • Sedimentation techniques:
      • Eggs and cysts settle at the bottom due to higher density.
      • Example: Formalin-ether concentration increases detection sensitivity by 8–10 times.
    • Flotation techniques:
      • Specimens are suspended in a denser medium (e.g., saturated salt solution) in which the eggs and cysts float.
      • Limitations: Cannot concentrate non-floating parasites (e.g., unfertilized Ascaris eggs).

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss over the past two weeks. She mentions that she recently traveled to a rural area for a camping trip and drank untreated stream water during her stay. On physical examination, no fever is noted, but mild tenderness is present in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Stool examination reveals the presence of trophozoites and cysts with characteristic "falling leaf" motility under microscopy. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Giardia lamblia

  • Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss. The "falling leaf" motility pattern is a classic finding seen in Giardia infections. This motility pattern is due to the unique flagella arrangement of Giardia trophozoites. The fact that the patient drank untreated stream water during her camping trip makes Giardia infection a likely culprit, as it is transmitted via contaminated water sources.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is a bacterium that causes typhoid fever. It typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, and constipation rather than diarrhea. The symptoms described in the scenario, including frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and "falling leaf" motility in the stool, are not characteristic of Salmonella typhi infection.

Option B - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery. While it can lead to diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, the "falling leaf" motility is not a characteristic finding for Entamoeba histolytica. Additionally, there is no mention of bloody diarrhea or the presence of colonic ulcers, which are often associated with this infection.

Option D - Cryptosporidium parvum: Cryptosporidium parvum is another protozoan parasite that causes diarrhea. However, the symptoms of cryptosporidiosis are generally more severe in immunocompromised individuals. The stool examination findings in cryptosporidiosis typically reveal oocysts, which are not described as "falling leaf" motility.

questions.text: A patient from a rural area is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loss of vision, headaches, confusion, and neck stiffness for the past 12 days. The electron microscopy image is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acanthamoeba

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation is indicative of granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE).
  • Electron microscopy reveals double-walled cysts, which are characteristic of Acanthamoeba.
  • Infections caused by Acanthamoeba are typically observed in immunocompromised rather than immunocompetent individuals.

 

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites.
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes:
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.

 

Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE)

GAE has an insidious onset, and the incubation period varies from several weeks to months.

  • Symptoms: Confusion, dizziness, nausea, headache, stiff neck and rarely seizure and hemiplegia.
  • In HIV/immunocompromised patients: In addition to GAE, Acanthamoeba produces nasal ulcers, cutaneous ulcers and musculoskeletal abscesses.
  • Pathology: Focal granulomatous lesions in the brain.
  • CSF analysis: Lymphocytosis is seen. However, in patients with AIDS, no cells are seen in CSF.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Brain biopsy: shows trophozoites and cysts.
    • Culture: NNA (Non-Nutrient Agar) – lawn culture of Escherichia coli.
    • Molecular methods: Multiplex real-time PCR.
    • Imaging method: CT scan or MRI reveals space-occupying or ring-enhancing lesions in the brain.
    • Treatment: Pentamidine + Azole + Sulfonamide + Flucytosine.

Trophozoite

Cyst

  • Show spikes (Acantho - Spikes)

  • Double-walled, with an outer wrinkled cyst wall.

 

Vs Balamuthia mandrillaris Infection: (Option C ruled out)

  • Also causes Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE).
  • The life cycle is similar to Acanthamoeba, and has trophozoites and cysts.
  • Unlike Acanthamoeba, Balamuthia encephalitis has been found in immunocompetent individuals.
  • Differences from Acanthamoeba
    • Trophozoite is fish-shaped.
    • The cyst is smoother.
    • It can occur in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised.

Naegleria fowleri (Option A): Naegleria fowleri causes primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). It is a free-living amoeba commonly found in warm freshwater environments. In nature, it exists in two forms: cysts and trophozoites.

  • Cyst: Round
  • Trophozoite: Can occur in two forms – amoeboid and flagellated forms.

questions.text: Infection in humans occurs by ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts through contaminated food or water. Which of the following is likely the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Entamoeba Histolytica

Explanation:

  • Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebiasis (also known as amoebic dysentery). It is transmitted through the ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts found in contaminated food or water. These cysts are ingested and then transform into trophozoites in the intestines, where they can cause symptoms ranging from mild diarrhea to severe dysentery and, in some cases, liver abscesses.
  • E.histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and a wide range of other invasive diseases, including amoebic liver abscesses.

Morphology: Has three stages:

  1. Trophozoite
  2. Precyst
  3. Cyst

Life Cycle:

  • Host: Single host, i.e. man.
  • Infective form: Mature quadrinucleate cyst
  • Mode of transmission: E. histolytica is transmitted by
    • Feco-oral route (most common)
    • Sexual (anogenital or orogenital) contact
    • Very rarely by vectors (mechanical transmission from faeces).
  • Development in Human Intestine:
    • Small intestine: Undergoes excystation
    • Large intestine: Multiplication and colonization.
  • Manifestations:
    • Asymptomatic cyst passers
    • Amoebic dysentery
    • Invasive amoebiasis
  • Encystation: When the lesions start healing, and the patient improves, trophozoites transform into cysts and then into cysts in the large intestine, which are liberated in faeces. These cysts are infective.

Giardia lamblia (Option A): The life cycle of Giardia lamblia involves ingestion of cysts from contaminated food or water. These cysts transform into trophozoites in the small intestine, multiply, and eventually form new cysts that are excreted in the feces to infect new hosts. This causes giardiasis.

Cryptosporidium parvum (Option C): This protozoan causes cryptosporidiosis, typically transmitted through contaminated water, but it does not involve quadrinucleate cysts.

Cyclospora cayetanensis (Option D): This parasite causes cyclosporiasis, which is also transmitted via contaminated food or water, but its cysts are not quadrinucleate.

questions.text:
Consider the following assertion and reason regarding Plasmodium falciparum infection:

Assertion: P. falciparum doesn’t show schizont stage in peripheral blood.

Reason: They get sequestered in small capillaries due to attachment to membranes.

Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.
Both the assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion.
The assertion is correct, but the reason is incorrect.
The assertion is incorrect, but the reason is correct.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.:

  • Schizonts of P. falciparum are not seen in the peripheral blood, they are seen only in the brain vasculature.

  • This is due to the cytoadherence property of P. falciparum.

Red blood cell

↓

Infected by P.falciparum (infects brain)

↓

P.falciparum starts making knobs - PF-Erythrocyte Membrane Protein

↓

These knobs will bind to ICAM present in endothelial cells

↓

The cell will get adhered - Cytoadherence

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oocysts of size 20-30 microns and oval shaped organisms, as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cystoisospora:

  • Cystoisospora belli are long and oval shaped organisms, measuring 20-33 micron in size.
  • These organisms affect immunosuppressed patients, particularly those with AIDS, often presenting with profuse diarrhea associated with weakness, anorexia, and weight loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cryptosporidium:

  • Cryptosporidium is 4-6 micron in size and round in shape.

Option C - Cyclospora:

  • Cyclospora is 8-12 micron in size and round in shape.

Option D - Microsporidia:

  • Microsporidia is 1-4 micron in size and possesses a polar tubule.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for identifying malaria species?

choices.text: Acridine orange stain with thin smear

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Giemsa stain with thin smear:

  • Thin smear with Giemsa stain under light microscopy is gold standard in the identification of malarial species.
  • Sensitivity: 200 parasites/microlitre.
  • Jaswant singh and Bhattacharya staining is preferred as per National malaria program.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Quantitative buffy coat:

  • Quantitative buffy coat is the microhematocrit method of diagnosing malaria. But it is not the best test for malaria speciation identification.

Option C - Thick smear with Giemsa stain:

  • Thick smear with Giemsa stain is the gold standard for quantification. Sensitivity is 5 parasites/microlitre

Option D - Acridine orange stain with thin smear:

  • Acridine orange stain with thin smear is expensive and not advised as per National malaria program.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites demonstrates parthenogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Strongyloides:

  • Parthenogenesis is the ability of the females to reproduce asexually.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode that is capable of Parthenogenesis.
  • Egg is not seen in Strongyloides stercoralis- Ovoviviparous

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D: These options are incorrect as these parasites are not capable of Parthenogenesis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

The clinical scenario indicates cerebral malaria. Plasmodium falciparum is one of the species of Plasmodium that causes cerebral malaria in humans characterized by high fever, headache, anorexia, nausea, anemia, hypotension, tachycardia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, and coma. The presence of "headphone-shaped/banana shaped" trophozoites in the blood smear is characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum, which is the causative agent of malaria.

questions.text: A Patient who has a pet dog at home complains of hypochondrial pain. Radiological imaging shows a multilocular cyst within the liver. The organism involved is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Echinococcus granulosus

Explanation: The patient’s symptoms of hypochondrial pain (pain in the upper abdomen), along with radiological findings of a multilocular cyst in the liver, strongly suggest an infection with Echinococcus granulosus, which causes hydatid disease.

Echinococcus granulosus

Other name

Dog tapeworm

Definitive Host

Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox

Intermediate Host

Sheep and cattle

Accidental Intermediate Host

Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form)

Infective Form

Embryonated egg

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the eggs due to:

  • Intimate handling of infected dogs
  • Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces

Eggs

  • Ovoid in shape and brown in color
  • Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets

Larva

Represent structure of scolex of adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body.

Adult Worm
  • Consist of scolex, a short neck and strobila
  • Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets.

                                                Life Cycle:

 

Hydatid Cyst

Hydatid cysts are parasitic cysts caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

Commonly Affected Organs

  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features:

  • Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.
  • Symptomatic Phase:
    • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
    • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Layers of a hydatid cyst

Layer

Name

Origin

Description

Main Function

Outer Layer

Pericyst

Host-derived
  • Thick fibrous layer created by the host's inflammatory response around the cyst.
  • Eventually it develops into a dense fibrous capsule which may even calcify.

Provides structural support and isolates the cyst from surrounding tissues.

Middle Layer

Ectocyst (Laminated Membrane)

Parasite-derived
  • Acellular,chitinous, laminated hyaline layer secreted by the parasite.
  • Has the appearance of the white of a hard boiled egg.

Acts as a barrier against host immune cells and protects the inner germinal layer.

Inner Layer

Endocyst (Germinal Layer)

Parasite-derived
  • Thin cellular layer lining the cyst interior.
  • Consist of a number of nuclei embedded in a protoplasmic mass.
  • Vital layer of the cyst.
  • Site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.
  • Also secrete hydatid fluid, which fills the cyst.

Entamoeba histolytica (Option B): This protozoan causes amoebic liver abscesses, which can also lead to right upper quadrant pain. However, the cysts in amoebic infections are typically unilocular, not multilocular, and are usually associated with a history of dysentery or diarrhea.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C): This is a parasitic roundworm that causes strongyloidiasis and may lead to abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, it does not typically cause multilocular cysts in the liver.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option D): This hookworm is associated with hookworm infection, causing symptoms like anemia and abdominal discomfort, but it does not lead to liver cysts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a long-standing history of fever presents with discoloration of the skin over the lower limb and edema. Microscopy reveals a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wuchereria bancrofti:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis. The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi’s microfilariae have two nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail.

Option C - Loa Loa: The microfilariae of Loa Loa are sheathed, but the nuclei form a continuous row at the tip of the tail.

Option D - Mansonelia: The microfilariae of Mansonelia are unsheathed and extend to the tip of the tail.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a history of gastrointestinal helminth infection has a stool sample showing motile 200-micron larvae but no eggs. Identify the parasite:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strongyloides:

  • Rhabditiform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis hatch and migrate to the intestinal lumen and are excreted in stool. No eggs are seen.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D: Eggs are present in the stool sample.

questions.text: A patient presents with perianal itching. A perianal swab was taken, and the image below shows the findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enterobius vermicularis:

  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes perianal itching, particularly at night, due to the female worm laying eggs around the anus. Diagnosis is typically made by identifying the characteristic D-shaped eggs using the scotch tape test or NIH swab.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hymenolepis nana: The dwarf tapeworm typically causes abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea but not perianal itching.

Options B and D - Ancylostoma and Necator americanus: Ancylostoma, now known as Necator americanus, is a hookworm that primarily causes iron deficiency anemia, ground itch, and creeping eruption.

questions.text: Field test for malaria?
questions.solution:
Hrp 2/Card test is quick and easy test which is used as field test for malaria.

 

  • The gold standard test used for the diagnosis of malaria is microscopy using the Romanowsky stain.
  • This method allows direct visualisation of malaria parasites within red blood cells, providing information about the species, parasite density, and stage of development.
  • It is highly specific and widely used, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF MALARIA

Microscopy (Gold standard)
  • Thick smear - for rapid detection of malarial parasite
    • Quantification is done under an oil immersion lens
      • + - 1 to 10 parasites per 100-thick film field
      • ++ - 11 to 100 parasites per 100 thick film field
      • +++ - 10 to 10 per thick film field
      • ++++ - more than 10 per thick film field
    • At least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a film is declared negative.
    • It can be used for the detection of malarial parasites as low as 20 parasites / μL
 
  • Thin smear - for determination of plasmodium species

 
  • Stains used - Romanowsky stain (Leishman, Giemsa or JSB stain)

Quantitative buffy coat test
  • RBCs with parasites are less dense; thus, concentrate just below the buffy coat of WBC on top of the RBC column
  • Acridine orange is used to induce fluorescence on the parasite, giving a fluorescent greenish-yellow appearance on a red background
  • Microscopic examination of a smear made using the buffy coat is done.

Kawamoto fluorescence microscopy

  • Fluorescent dye like acridine orange or benzothiocarboxy purine is used to stain the parasite inside the RBC
  • Parasite DNA is stained fluorescent green, and cytosol RNA is stained red
  • The slide is examined under the fluorescent microscope
  • Used for mass screening in field laboratory

Rapid antigen detection test

  • Immunochromatography is done using monoclonal antibody directed against the parasite antigen

Parasite F test

  • Monoclonal antibody is used to detect histidine-rich protein 2 (HRP-2), which is produced by asexual stages of plasmodium falciparum
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Can detect low parasitemia (40 parasite / μL of blood)
    • Can detect only the asexual stage of plasmodium falciparum

Dual antigen test
  • Detects Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) and Plasmodium falciparum histidine-rich protein (PfHRP-2)
  • pLDH is produced by trophozoites and gametocytes of all plasmodium spp.
  • PfHRP-2 is produced only by the asexual stage of Plasmodium falciparum.

Molecular method

  • PCR: Used for species determination and detection of drug resistance.
  • DNA probe: Highly sensitive and can detect less than 10 parasites / μL of blood.

questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica?
questions.solution:
Triclabendazole is DOC for fasciola hepatica.

 

Fasciola hepatica


Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction, and inflammatory reactions.

 

Morphology

Adult Fluke:

 

 

  • Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad.
  • Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width.
  • Color: Typically brown or grey.
  • Distinctive Features:
    • Cone-shaped anterior end.
    • Two suckers, an oral sucker at the front and a ventral sucker close to it, used for attachment to host tissues.
    • The fluke’s body is covered by a tegument (a protective outer layer) with spines aiding in attachment.

 

Eggs:

 

 

  • Size: Large, oval, and approximately 130-150 µm in length.
  • Color: Yellowish-brown.
  • Characteristics:
    • Each egg has an operculum (a lid-like structure) at one end, which opens to release the miracidium (the larval stage).
    • Eggs are unembryonated when passed out in feces.

 

Life Cycle

 

 

  1. Eggs in Water
  • Eggs are expelled in the feces of infected mammals (definitive hosts).
  • Under suitable environmental conditions, miracidia are released from eggs after 9–15 days.
  1. Infection of Snails (Intermediate Host)
  • Miracidia penetrate specific freshwater snails, such as Lymnaea spp.
  • Inside the snail, they progress through stages: sporocyst, redia, and eventually cercaria.
  1. Release and Encystment
  • Cercariae exit the snail and encyst on aquatic vegetation, transforming into metacercariae, the infective stage.
  1. Infection of Mammals (Definitive Host)
  • Mammals, including humans, become infected by consuming contaminated water or vegetation with metacercariae.
  • In the duodenum, metacercariae excyst, penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate to the liver, and lodge in the bile ducts, maturing into adult flukes.

 

Clinical Presentation

Acute Phase (Invasive or Hepatic Stage):

  • Duration: Begins about 2-3 weeks post-infection and may last for several months.
  • Symptoms:
    • Fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
    • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and occasionally jaundice.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
    • Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil count in blood).

Chronic Phase (Biliary Stage):

  • Duration: Occurs months to years post-infection.
  • Symptoms:
    • Biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, and cholangitis (inflammation of the bile ducts).
    • Gallbladder symptoms, liver abscesses, and secondary bacterial infections in severe cases.
    • Possible fibrosis of the bile ducts with prolonged infection.

 

Investigations

  1. Serology:
    • ELISA for detection of anti-Fasciola antibodies (sensitive in both acute and chronic infections).
    • Immunoblotting can also confirm the diagnosis.
  2. Stool Examination:
    • Microscopic detection of eggs in stool samples; however, eggs are typically not present in the acute phase and may be difficult to detect in chronic cases.
  3. Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Useful in detecting hepatobiliary abnormalities such as bile duct dilation or liver abscesses.
    • CT/MRI: May show liver lesions or track the migration of larvae in the liver.
  4. Blood Tests:
    • Eosinophilia is common in the acute phase.
    • Liver function tests: Elevated liver enzymes, especially in chronic disease.

 

Management

Antiparasitic Treatment:

  • Triclabendazole: The drug of choice, effective against both adult and larval stages. Dosage: Oral dose of 10-12 mg/kg, with a repeat dose after 12 hours if needed.

Alternative Medications:

  • Bithionol: Sometimes used if triclabendazole is unavailable.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leishmania tropica

Explanation:

  • Leishmania tropica causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, also known as oriental sore, which is endemic in parts of Rajasthan. It presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcer with surrounding erythema. The amastigote form, seen on microscopy, has a characteristic dark-staining nucleus and kinetoplast inside macrophages.
  • Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease caused by a protozoan species belonging to the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by sand fly vectors.

 

Clinical manifestations of Leishmaniasis vary, depending on the species, from cutaneous ulcers to systemic multiorgan disease.

Mucocutaneous involvement can be seen in:

a. Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL)

I. Old world leishmaniasis - caused by L. major/ L. tropica

II. New world leishmaniasis - caused by L. mexicana

 

CL typically begins as a pink-coloured papule that enlarges, then develops into a nodule or plaque, finally forming a painless ulceration with an indurated border.

Old World CL: The ulcer is often covered with hyperkeratotic eschar. The ulcer margins may be raised (volcano sign).

New World CL: The ulcer may be covered with thick white-yellow fibrinous material. ‘Chiclero’s ulcer’ - multiple, small, chronic ulcers on the ear, due to multiple sandfly bites.

 

b. Mucosal Leishmaniasis (ML) caused by L. braziliensis

  • Characterized by mucosal destruction. The most commonly involved tissues include the nose, mouth, and nasal septum.
  • Symptoms include nasal stuffiness and mucosal bleeding, while some experience pain and deformity. Substantial disfigurement can result.

Incorrect Options:

Babesia (Option B): Babesia is an intracellular parasite that affects red blood cells, causing malaria-like hemolytic anemia, fever, and thrombocytopenia, not skin ulcers.

Trypanosoma cruzi (Option C): Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which presents with Romana's sign (unilateral periorbital swelling) and cardiomyopathy, rather than cutaneous ulcers. The trypomastigote form is seen in blood smears, not in tissue biopsy.

Histoplasma (Option D): Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that primarily causes pulmonary infections. Though it can cause cutaneous lesions in disseminated histoplasmosis, it lacks the kinetoplast seen in protozoal parasites like Leishmania.

questions.text: Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

The given image is of trophozoite stage of Giardia lamblia

Giardia lamblia:

  • It includes 2 stages:
    • Trophozoite (or vegetative form)
    • Cysts (or cystic form).
  • Infective form: Mature cyst
  • Transmission: Feco oral route.
  • Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum.
  • Ingesting a minimum of 10 cysts can cause an infection in a person.
  • Within half an hour of ingestion, the cyst hatches out into two trophozoites, which multiply successively by binary fission and colonise the duodenum.
  • During unfavorable condition , encystment occurs and cyst are passed in stool and remain viable in soil and water for several weeks.
  • Life cycle: Host (only human) → Contaminated food and water (faeco-oral route) → Cyst (ingested form) → excystation occurs → Trophozoite.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Sample: Stool
    • Microscopy: Cyst and trophozoite are seen.
      • Trophozoite: 2 nuclei and four pairs of flagella with pear-shaped or tennis racket-shaped.
  • Cyst: 1-4 nuclei and no flagella.
  • String test: A capsule will have a string, and the capsule is swallowed, then the capsule goes to duodenum and dissolves, then the string is pulled back and, a microscopic examination is done.
  • Duodenal biopsy:
    • Giardia lamblia is a luminal organism
    • Organisms hanging in the lumen
    • Sickle shaped organism is seen.
    • Falling leaf motility is shown.
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole
    • Tinidazole (single dose of 2g)

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option B) The trophozoite of Trichomonas is a pyriform or oval-shaped organism with 4 flagella on the anterior end, and 5th flagella remain folded on the outer surface of the undulating membrane. An axosystole runs throughout the length of the body.

Trypanosoma (Option C) is a hemoflagellate with 4 different morphological forms all of them containing 1 nucleus, and kinetoplast. Different forms are Amastigote, Promastigote, Epimastigote and Trypomastigote.

Cyclospora (Option D) It is a coccidian Protozoa, which is usually identified by its oocysts. Sporulated oocysts of cyclospora are round in shape as well as acid-fast, but contain 2 sporocysts, with each sporocyst containing two sporozoites.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Taenia solium?

choices.text: Eggs are not infective to man
The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
Correct answer C) The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution:

Explanation:

Taenia solium eggs are heavier and do not float in saturated salt solution during stool examination. Instead, they settle at the bottom, requiring sedimentation techniques for diagnosis.

Eggs are not infective to man (Option A): Taenia solium eggs are infective to humans and cause cysticercosis when ingested. Humans can act as both definitive and intermediate hosts for Taenia solium.

Hooks are absent (Option B) Taenia solium has a scolex (head) with hooks and suckers, which helps in attachment to the intestinal wall. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) lacks hooks.

Intermediate host is cow (Option D): The intermediate host for Taenia solium is the pig (pork tapeworm). Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) has cows as intermediate hosts.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is incorrect?

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction.
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent.
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy.

questions.solution:
Given CT scan is that of Renal Hydatid Cyst showing cystic structures surrounded by a rim of calcifications.

  • FNAC or biopsy should never be done before nephrectomy in case of a hydatid cyst as it contains lots of hydatid fluid, which can produce an anaphylactic reaction in the patient.

 

Management of Echinococcus granulosus

Management is guided by the WHO classification (CE1-CE5) and depends on cyst stage, location, symptoms, and complication risk.

Pharmacotherapy

Albendazole and Praziquantel:

  • Albendazole is the drug of choice for uncomplicated cysts, used to prevent recurrence and to reduce the size of the cyst before surgery or PAIR.
  • Praziquantel serves as an adjunct therapy to enhance treatment efficacy.

 

PAIR Technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration): Best mode of treatment of cysts

 

Steps:

  1. Puncture: Insert needle into cyst under ultrasound or CT guidance.
  2. Aspiration: Partially aspirate cyst fluid to reduce pressure.
  3. Injection: Inject scolicidal agent (e.g., hypertonic saline, ethanol, cetrimide) into cyst.
  4. Reaspiration: Re-aspirate injected fluid to remove cyst contents and scolicidal agent.

 

  • Minimally Invasive: Effective for unilocular cysts (CE1 and CE3a); involves puncturing and injecting a scolicidal agent.
  • Advantages: Lower recurrence risk and shorter hospital stays.
  • Contraindications: Not suitable for
    • Cysts with extensive daughter cysts or at risk of rupture
    • Calcified cyst

 

Percutaneous Drainage (PERC): An alternative to PAIR for draining cysts without scolicidal agents.

 

Surgical Management

Cystectomy or Pericystectomy:

For large, complicated, or ruptured cysts; it is preferred for CE2 and CE3b cysts or challenging anatomical locations.

 

Watch and Wait:

Inactive or Calcified Cysts (CE4 and CE5) can often be observed safely with regular imaging follow-up.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 0, 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once.
Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days.

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of seizures, fever, and peripheral smear reveals a headphone-shaped or multiple-ring form that is suggestive of cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

 

  • Artemisinin derivatives are the first-line agent in case of cerebral malaria. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg is given intravenously at 0, 12, and 24 hours, followed by daily once given in case of cerebral malaria.

 

Plasmodium vivax or ovale

Plasmodium falciparum

Mixed infection

Chloroquine + Primaquine

  • Chloroquine 25 mg for 3 days as 10 mg/kg on day 1, 10 mg/kg on day 2 and 5 mg/kg on day 3.
  • Primaquine 0.25 mg/kg body wt for 14 days

Primaquine + ACT

 

ACT (Artemisinin-based combination therapy):

  • All Indian states (except northeastern): Artesunate (4 mg/kg body weight) + sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) or pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight)
  • Northeastern states: Artemether (20 mg) + Lumefantrine (120 mg)

ACT+ Primaquine 0.25 mg per kg body weight daily for 14 days

 

  • ACT for chloroquine-resistant malaria:
    • Artesunate + Mefloquine
    • Artesunate + Amodiaquine
    • Artesunate + Pyronaridine (used in China)
    • Arterolane + Piperaquine

 

  • In Artemisinin allergic individuals:
    • QDC regimen: Quinidine + Doxycycline + Clindamycin

 

Management of Complicated malaria (acute severe malaria)

  • Supportive and emergency treatment as needed
  • IV Artesunate (drug of choice) Only Artemisinin to be given intravenously; rest are given intramuscularly)
  • IM Artemether
  • IM Arteether
  • IV Quinine in 5% dextrose solution (quinine cause hypoglycemia)

questions.text: On Cold Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining, oocysts of size 8-10 um cysts are visible. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cyclospora

 

Explanation:

This Cold ZN staining reveals the presence of 4 cyclospora round oocyst-bearing sporozoites of size 8-10 um, showing variability in staining in the field.

  • Cyclosporiasis is a disease caused by Cyclospora cayetanensis, transmitted by feces or feces-contaminated food and water

 

Cryptosporidium

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst in contaminated water

Clinical features

  • In Immunocompetent patients: Self-limited watery diarrhoea.
  • In Immunocompromised patients: Chronic persistent watery diarrhoea.

Microscopy

  • Appearance: Acid-fast, round oocyst
  • Size: 4–6 microns
  • Contents: Each oocyst contains four sporozoites
  • Types of oocyst:
    • Thick-walled - excreted out from host in faeces.
    • Thin-walled - involved in autoinfection.


 

 

Isospora

Cyclospora

Sarcocystis

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Clinical features

  • Mild fever with diarrhoea
  • Can cause chronic diarrhoea in the immunocompromised host
  • Formation of sarcocysts within the muscle fibres (Muscular sarcocystosis)
  • Nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhoea (Intestinal sarcocystosis)

Microscopy

Oocyte is oval, acid-fast, 24-36 microns and autofluorescent, containing 8 sporozoites.

Oocyte is round, acid variable, 8-10 microns and autofluorescent, containing 2 - 2 sporozoites in each wheel.

Sarcocysts are present between the muscle fibres; each cyst has numerous merozoites.


 

Pathogens causing diarrhoea in HIV-positive patients

Parasites

Cryptosporidium parvum (Most common)

Isospora belli

Cyclospora

Giardia lamblia

Entamoeba histolytica

Microsporidia spp

Bacteria

Shigella species (Most common)

Salmonella species

Viruses

Cytomegalovirus
