questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

Explanation:

Trichomoniasis

  • Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.
  • The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
    • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening
    • Painful urination
    • Pain during intercourse
    • Recurrent infections
    • Inflamed vulva
    • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix")
  • The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

Incorrect Options:

Trophozoite has 2 nuclei (Option A): Trichomonas vaginalis exists only as a trophozoite, which has a single nucleus and four anterior flagella, not two nuclei.

Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions (Option C): Trichomonas vaginalis does not form cysts; it exists only as a trophozoite.

Infective form is cyst (Option D): The infective form of T. vaginalis is the trophozoite, not a cyst. It is transmitted through sexual contact, and the absence of a cyst form contributes to its reliance on direct human-to-human transmission.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke that infects the biliary ducts, leading to chronic inflammation, epithelial hyperplasia, and fibrosis, which increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).

Cholangiocarcinoma

  • Cholangiocarcinoma is an aggressive adenocarcinoma of the bile ducts, commonly presenting as obstructive jaundice.

Risk Factors

  • Biliary and Liver Conditions:
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
    • Choledochal cyst
    • Hepatolithiasis
    • Caroli's disease
  • Infections:
    • Clonorchis sinensis infestation
    • Hepatitis B and C (risk factors for intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma)
  • Genetic Conditions:
    • Lynch syndrome II
  • Other Conditions:
    • Multiple biliary papillomatosis
    • Previous biliary enteric anastomosis
  • Toxins:
    • Thorotrast
    • Nitrosamines
    • Dioxin

Types based on its location

 

 

Clinical Features

  • Primary Presentation:
    • Painless obstructive jaundice of short duration
  • Liver Changes:
    • Palpable liver, which may be smooth and soft (hydrohepatotic) or hard and nodular (secondaries)
  • Other Symptoms:
    • Weight loss and anorexia (typical and significant)
  • Gender Prevalence:
    • More common in men (1.5:1)

Incorrect Options:

Cervical cancer (Option A): Cervical cancer is primarily caused by persistent HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

Gastric carcinoma (Option C): Chronic infection with Helicobacter pylori is a major risk factor for gastric carcinoma, but Clonorchis sinensis is not involved in gastric cancer development.

Bladder carcinoma (Option D): Schistosoma haematobium, not Clonorchis sinensis, is associated with bladder carcinoma, particularly squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder due to chronic inflammation and irritation.

questions.text: A boy presented with fever and chills. A rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

  • The Histidine-Rich Protein 2 (HRP-2) antigen is specific to P. falciparum and is widely used in rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for malaria.
  • This antigen is produced by the parasite and remains in circulation for several days after treatment, making it useful for detection but sometimes leading to false positives in recent infections.

Malaria

Agent

Plasmodium species

Species

Type

Fever Cycle

P.falciparum

Malignant Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.vivax

Benign Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.malariae

Quartan Malaria

Every 72 hours

P.ovale

Ovale Malaria

Every 48 hours

P. knowlesi

Quotidian Malaria

Every 24 hours (daily)

Incubation Period: 7-30 days, depending on Plasmodium species

Vector

Female Anopheles mosquitoes

  • Behavior: Nocturnal feeders; prefer to bite between dusk and dawn
  • Breeding Sites: Stagnant water bodies such as ponds, marshes, swamps, and artificial containers

Transmission
  • Bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes
  • Can be transmitted through blood transfusions and organ transplants.

Host
  • Humans (Primary Host)
  • Higher risk in pregnant women, infants, and immunocompromised
  • Anopheles mosquitoes (Vector and Intermediate host)

Environmental Factors
  • Climate: Warm and Humid environment
  • Seasonality: Rainy seasons
  • Geographical Distribution:
    • Most prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions
    • India: Endemic in several states, particularly in the northeastern states (Assam, Tripura, Meghalaya), Eastern states (Odisha, Jharkhand), and some parts of Maharashtra and Karnataka

Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium malariae (Option B): P. malariae is not detected by HRP-2-based tests, as it lacks this antigen. Instead, it is diagnosed via microscopy or PCR.

Plasmodium vivax (Option C): P. vivax is typically detected using lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH)-based RDTs, not HRP-2 tests. HRP-2 does not reliably detect P. vivax infections.

Plasmodium ovale (Option D): Like P. vivax, P. ovale lacks HRP-2 and is not detected by HRP-2-based rapid tests. Its diagnosis depends on microscopy or PCR.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites invade the skin directly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schistosoma mansoni

Explanation:

  • Schistosoma species (including S. mansoni, S. haematobium, and S. japonicum) penetrate human skin directly when a person comes in contact with contaminated freshwater containing cercariae (infective larval stage). This leads to swimmer’s itch followed by systemic schistosomiasis.

 

Schistosoma (Blood Fluke):

Species

  • Schistosoma haematobium (Africa, Near East, Middle East, India)
  • Schistosoma mansoni (Africa, South America)
  • Schistosoma japonicum (China, Japan, Far East)

Habitat

  • S. haematobium: Veins of vesical and pelvic plexuses
  • S. mansoni: Inferior mesenteric vein
  • S. japonicum: Superior mesenteric vein

Definitive Host

Man

Intermediate Host

Snail

Mode of Infection

Skin penetration by cercaria

Infective form

Cercaria larva

Eggs

Has characteristic lateral spine.

Larva

Has following stages:

  • Miracida
  • Sporocysts
  • Cercaria: Has elongated ovoid body and forked tail.

Adult worm
  • Sexes are separate.
  • Has 2 muscular suckers: Oral and ventral sucker
  • Gynecophoric canal begins behind the ventral sucker, where the female worm is held.

 

Life Cycle:

 

Clonorchis sinensis (Option B): This liver fluke is transmitted through ingestion of raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing metacercariae, not by direct skin penetration. It causes biliary tract infections and is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Wuchereria bancrofti (Option C): This filarial parasite is transmitted by mosquito bites, not by direct skin penetration. It causes lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis) due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels.

Diphyllobothrium latum (Option D): This tapeworm is acquired through ingestion of raw freshwater fish containing plerocercoid larvae, not through skin penetration. It can cause vitamin B12 deficiency leading to megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient who presents with fever and a positive filarial antigen test?

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

Explanation:

  • A filarial antigen test is highly sensitive but does not differentiate between active and past infections.
  • The next step is to confirm the presence of microfilariae in a peripheral blood smear, preferably collected at night (due to nocturnal periodicity of Wuchereria bancrofti).
  • Thick and thin smears with Giemsa or Wright’s stain are used to visualize microfilariae.

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

DEC provocation test:
  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour
  • Microfilariae can appear in the daytime.
  • Highest specificity

5.

Serological tests
  • Cannot differentiate between past and present infection

6.

Mass blood survey
  • Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

Incorrect Options:

Bone marrow biopsy (Option A): Filarial infections affect the lymphatic system and do not require a bone marrow biopsy.

DEC provocation test (Option B): The Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) provocation test was historically used to stimulate microfilariae circulation, but it is rarely used today due to the availability of antigen detection tests.

Ultrasound of the scrotum (Option D): Ultrasound of the scrotum (for "Filarial Dance Sign" - movement of microfilariae in dilated lymphatic channels) is useful if scrotal involvement or hydrocele is present, but it is not the first-line confirmatory test.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. CT head imaging reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is the correct approach to management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continue antiepileptics

Explanation:

Seizures due to calcified neurocysticercosis should be managed with long-term antiepileptic therapy (e.g., levetiracetam, phenytoin, or valproate). Antiparasitic drugs are not needed for calcified lesions.

  • Multiple calcified parenchymal cysts on CT head are characteristic of neurocysticercosis (NCC) in the inactive (calcified) stage.
  • Seizures in calcified NCC are caused by gliotic scarring rather than active infection, so the primary treatment is antiepileptic therapy.
  • Antiparasitic drugs (Albendazole, Praziquantel) are ineffective in the calcified stage and can worsen inflammation.
  • Steroids are used only if perilesional edema is present, but they do not alter the course of calcified cysts.
  • The combination of albendazole and praziquantel is recommended for effective treatment of multiple viable cysts (>2 cysts).

 

Treatment of Neurocysticercosis

  1. Seizure Management: Anticonvulsant therapy is initiated upon seizure presentation. Stop if follow-up imaging shows resolution and no seizures for 24 months.
  2. Anthelmintic Therapy: Depends on the lesion stage.
  3. Cystic Lesions Treatment:
    • Albendazole: Drug of choice for parenchymal neurocysticercosis (15 mg/kg daily for 10-14 days). Recommended for 1-2 parenchymal cysts.
    • Praziquantel: Alternative option (50 mg/kg in 3 divided doses daily for 10 days).
    • Albendazole + Praziquantel: For >2 viable cysts (Praziquantel: 50 mg/kg/day for 10-14 days).
    • Prednisolone: 10 mg three times daily for 14 days, starting 1 day before albendazole or praziquantel. Given to suppress the inflammation during the natural course of the disease.
  4. Stages of Cysts:
    • Viable Cysts: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Vesicular & Colloidal Stages: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Granulonodular Stage: Some experts recommend treatment.
    • Calcified Lesions: Do not require treatment with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Small, Solitary Cerebral Cysts: Often resolve without treatment.
  5. Operative Intervention: Indicated for hydrocephalus.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is the adult form of echinococcus observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dog:

  • The adult worm of Echinococcus lives in the jejunum and duodenum of dogs and other canine carnivora ( wolf and fox).
  • The larval stage (hydatid cyst) is found in humans and herbivorous animals like sheep, goats, cattle, and horses.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: For which condition is the Sabin-Feldman dye test utilized in diagnosing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxoplasmosis:

  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a gold standard test for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. It is a type of complement fixation test that detects the presence of specific antibodies, known as Toxoplasma-specific antibodies, in a person's blood.
  • It involves mixing the patient's serum with live tachyzoites from Toxoplasma gondii and then adding a dye (methylene blue). If antibodies are present, the tachyzoites will be colorless, and if antibodies are absent, the tachyzoites will show color. The presence of antibodies will activate the complement fixation and destroy the tachyzoites, and lead to distorted and colorless tachyzoites.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. The Sabin-Feldman dye test is specific and sensitive to toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sandfly:

  • The given image is Leishman Donovan bodies, which are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size, suggesting typical Leishmaniasis.
  • The vector for the transmission of leishmaniasis is sandfly, particularly Phlebotomous argentipes and orientalis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Neurocysticercosis is caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cysticercus Cellulose:

  • Neurocysticercosis is caused by the larva of Taenia solium called cysticercus cellulosae.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cysticercus Bovis: It is the larval stage of Taenia saginata responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

Option B - Taenia Saginata Asiatica: Taenia saginata asiatica is another species of tapeworm that resembles Taenia saginata, and cysticerci are located in liver.

Option D - Taenia Saginata: Taenia saginata is responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Filariasis:

  • The Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) is carried out for filariasis, which is caused by parasitic worms transmitted through mosquito bites. The TAS helps assess the transmission of filariasis, monitor the progress of elimination programs, and determine if interventions have successfully reduced the prevalence of the disease in endemic areas or if mass drug administration is required or not.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Transmission assessment survey is one for Filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Echinococcus Multilocularis:

  • Echinococcus multilocularis is a parasitic tapeworm that causes alveolar echinococcosis. It can form multiple cyst and inside single cyst multiple locules are present leading to multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, hence called alveolar hydatid cyst/multilocularis. The lesions are invasive and can infiltrate surrounding tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Echinococcus Granulosus: Echinococcus granulosus is another parasitic tapeworm that causes hydatid cysts. Multiple cysts are present, filled with fluid, which may cause anaphylaxis if drained in the body.

Option C - Entamoeba Histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses. It affects the right lobe of the liver and presents with an abscess described as anchovy sauce.

Option D - Cysticercus Cellulosae: Cysticercus cellulosae is the larval stage of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium responsible for causing cysticercosis, characterized by multiple calcified cysts an multiple organs.

questions.text: Following vector is not involved in transmission of which of the following disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kyasanur Forest Disease:

  • The vector shown in the image is a sandfly. Points for identification.
    • Light or dark brown flies, smaller than mosquitoes.
    • Body and wings covered by dense hair.
    • Head contains a pair of long, slender, and hairy antennae, palpi, and a proboscis.
    • Thorax contains a pair of wings and three pairs of legs.
  • Diseases caused by sandflies are Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Sandfly fever, Oriental sore, and Oroya fever.
  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD), also known as monkey fever, is caused by the Kyasanur Forest Disease virus (KFDV). Hard ticks are the main vectors involved in the transmission of Kyasanur Forest Disease.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These diseases are transmitted by sandfly.

questions.text: Which is the agent used to treat the infection caused by the cestode egg in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Praziquantel:

  • The given image is the Egg of Hymenolepis nana. The egg is round to slightly oval in shape. It has two membranes that surround an embryo with six hooklets. The space between the two membranes is filled by yolk granules. Both the poles of the embryophore are thickened.
  • The drug of choice to treat the infection is praziquantel works by causing severe spasms and paralysis of the tapeworm's muscles, leading to the detachment of the worm from the intestinal wall. It also increases the permeability of the tapeworm's cells to calcium ions, which ultimately results in the worm's death.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These drugs are not the drug of choice to treat infection caused by H. nana.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strongyloides Stercoralis:

  • The image represents the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis. Points for identification.
  • Females are capable of asexual reproduction (Parthenogenesis)
  • Ovoviviparous larva comes out immediately from the egg
  • Infective form: Filariform larva penetrates the intact skin of the definitive host.
  • Route: By penetration of the Skin/autoinfection
  • Rhabditiform larva comes first and transforms into filariform larva in 3 ways:
    • Autoinfection: Penetrate intestine, produce Filariform larva
    • Direct cycle: Rhabditiform larvae exit the body and transform into Filariform larvae, and re-enters the body.
    • Indirect cycle
      • Rhabditiform larva forms adult(male and female), lays eggs
      • Eggs develop into Rhabditiform larvae
      • Rhabditiform larva transforms into Filariform larva

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ancylostoma Duodenale: Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans by penetrating the skin and migrating to the intestines. Its life cycle does not involve autoinfection.

Option C - Ascaris Lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large roundworm that infects humans. Its life cycle does not involve autoinfection.

Option D - Enterobius Vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, is a small nematode that commonly infects humans. Its life cycle involves the ingestion of eggs, hatching of larvae in the intestines, and migration to the colon and rectum for maturation and reproduction.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 μm) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoisospora:

  • Cystoisospora (formerly known as Isospora) is a genus of intracellular parasites that infect the gastrointestinal tract, leading to diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual. The oocysts of Cystoisospora are acid fast, 23-36 μm in size and are oval in shape.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cyclospora: The oocysts of Cyclospora are variably acid-fast, 8-12 μm in size, and round in shape.

Option C - Cryptosporidium: The oocyst of Cryptosporidium is acid-fast, 4-6 μm in size, and round in shape.

Option D - Microsporidia: Microsporidia are intracellular parasites characterized by a unicellular spore containing a coiled spring-like tubular polar filament.

questions.text: Which infection is characterized by the presence of bloody diarrhea, liver abscess, and right upper quadrant pain, and histology of colon biopsy shows flask-shaped ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Entamoeba Histolytica:

  • The clinical presentation of bloody diarrhea, liver abscess, and flask-shaped ulcer is suggestive of Amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • The most commonly affected organ is the intestine leading to bloody diarrhea (traveler's diarrhea) and appendicitis. The most common extraintestinal infection occurs in liver which may lead to amebic liver abscess (anchovy sauce).
  • A colon biopsy shows a flask-shaped ulcer is characteristic of Entamoeba histolytica. The trophozoites of E. histolytica damage the mucosa and submucosa but cannot damage the muscular as it is difficult to break. Thus, it starts breaking the submucosa on the sides, resulting in a flask-shaped ulcer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia Lamblia: It is responsible for causing giardiasis characterized by steatorrhea due to malabsorption, not dysentery.

Option C - Campylobacter Jejuni: This is a gram-negative bacteria that causes fever, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is diagnosed by gram staining showing darting motility or by growing in culture.

Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacteria that can cause various infections, including food poisoning characterized by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. It can be diagnosed by gram staining and culture medium.

questions.text: The bone marrow aspirate from a patient revealed the following findings as seen in the image. Which of the following statements is correct about the disease?

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite:

  • The given image is Leishman Donovan bodies, which are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size, suggesting Leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan parasites of the Leishmania genus. These parasites infect various tissues of the body, including the bone marrow.
  • The gold standard test to diagnose leishmaniasis is by demonstration of the amastigote in peripheral blood, bone marrow aspirate, spleen aspirate, and large lymph nodes. Examination of buffy coat is best to examine for amastigote in peripheral blood smear. Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, with more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It is an obligate extracellular parasite: Leishmania parasites are obligate intracellular parasites, specifically residing inside macrophages and other immune cells. They are obligate intracellular parasites and require host cells for their survival and replication.

Option C - It is transmitted by culex: Leishmaniasis is primarily transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female sandflies.

Option D - Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India: The choice of treatment for leishmaniasis depends on various factors, including the species of Leishmania causing the infection and the geographical location. The drug of choice to treat leishmaniasis is liposomal amphotericin B, which is also used as a first-line treatment in different regions.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Continue antiepileptics

Explanation:

  • The management of a patient with seizures and multiple parenchymal cysts seen on the CT head depends on the underlying cause of the cysts
  • Calcified parenchymal cysts probably suggests neurocysticercosis, which is caused by larval cysts (Cysticercus cellulosae) of the pork tapeworm (Taenia solium).
  • The appropriate management for calcified parenchymal neurocysticercosis is symptomatic treatment with antiepileptic drugs to control the seizures.

questions.text: What is the most common mode of transmission for babesiosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ticks:

  • Babesiosis is a tick-borne disease. Ticks (Ixodid) act as vectors and can transmit the Babesia parasites to humans during a blood meal.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reduviid Bugs: Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi transmitted by reduviid bugs (triatomine).

Option B - Tsetse Fly: Sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei transmitted by tsetse fly.

Option C - Sand Fly: Leishmaniasisis caused by leishmania spp. is transmitted by sand fly.

questions.text: Which among the following occupations is a risk factor for this presenting illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kennel Worker:

  • The reddish serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis, as shown in the image, are suggestive of Cutaneous larva migrans caused by Ancylostoma braziliense. 
  • Kennel workers who handle and care for animals, including dogs and cats, are at an increased risk of exposure to the larvae of hookworms (Ancylostoma braziliense), which can cause cutaneous larva migrans (CLM). Ancylostoma braziliensis is transmitted by the larva which penetrates the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Kennel workers are at maximum risk of developing cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Babesia:

  • Babesia species are tick-borne parasites that primarily infect red blood cells. Sporozoites in the salivary gland of the ticks are transmitted to humans after bite and enters bloodstream. They change to trophozoites, invade red blood cells, and multiply asexually. Newly formed trophozoites are released by rupturing erythrocytes and invade new erythrocytes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Toxoplasma: The tachyzoites of T. gondii formed in the intestine can infect the brain, eye, liver, spleen, lung, and skeletal muscles and form tissue cysts.

Option B - Plasmodium: Plasmodium species are the causative agents of malaria. The pre-erythrocytic schizogony takes place in the liver.

Option D - Leishmania: The amastigote of the Leishmania donovani multiply enormously in the macrophages of the liver, bone marrow, and spleen.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and intense itching. On examination, the cervix appears strawberry-like. Which of the following statements is false regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It exists in cyst and trophozoite forms
The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM
The treatment of choice is metronidazole

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It exists in cyst and trophozoite forms:

  • The clinical presentation of foul-smelling frothy-vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix is suggestive of trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. 
  • Trichomonas vaginalis is an obligate parasite that exists only in trophozoite form, which is both diagnostic and infective stage.
    Diagnosis by culture is the gold standard test. It is cultured in Cysteine peptone liver maltose media (CPLM).
  • The drug of choice for trichomoniasis is a single dose of 2-gram metronidazole for both partners..

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: These statements are accurate about Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text:
Assertion: Malathion is used as ultra – low volume (ULV) during epidemics

Reason: Ultra low volume fogger has residual effects

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Assertion is true, but the reason is false:

  • The assertion states that Malathion is used as an ultra-low volume (ULV) during epidemics, which is true, and the reason that ultra-low volume defoggers have residual effects is wrong. Malathion is the least toxic organophosphorus compound commonly used as an insecticide during disease outbreaks, particularly for dengue-hemorrhagic fever and mosquito-borne encephalitis epidemics. ULV refers to the method of applying a small volume of insecticide as fine droplets, which allows for effective coverage and control of mosquitoes or other vector populations.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following parasite is transmitted by reduviid bug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T. Cruzi:

  • This parasite causes Chagas disease, also known as American trypanosomiasis. It is transmitted by the triatomine (reduviid) bug, commonly known as the "kissing bug." When the bug bites a person, it can defecate near the bite wound, and if the person scratches the area, the parasite can enter the bloodstream through the broken skin.

Incorrect Options

Option A - T. Brucei: It is known for causing African Trypanosomiasis, commonly known as Sleeping Sickness transmitted by tsetse fly.

Option C - Leishmania Donovani: It is known for causing visceral leishmaniasis, transmitted by sandflies.

Option D - Both A & B: Although both parasites belong to the genus Trypanosoma, T. Cruzi is transmitted by reduviid bug, and T. brucei is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.text: Two nuclei present at the tail tip are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brugia Malayi:

  • Sheathed microfilariae with 2 nuclei at the tip of the tail is suggestive of Brugia malayi.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wuchereria Bancrofti: Microfilariae of W. bancrofti are sheathed, but nuclei do not extend to the tail.

Option C - Loa Loa: Microfilariae of Loa loa are sheathed and bear a column of nuclei extending till the tail tip

Option D - Onchocerca Volvulus: Microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus are unsheathed, and nuclei do not extend to the tail tip.

questions.text: Smallest cestode is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - H. Nana:

  • Hymenolepsis nana is the smallest cestode, hence known as a dwarf cestode.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. H. nana is the smallest cestode.

questions.text: Identify parasite?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - E. Histolytica:

  • The given image is of E. histolytica trophozoites. Points for identification are:
  • It is 12 to 60 μm and actively motile in freshly passed dysenteric stool. Typical ameboid motility is a crawling or gliding movement.
  • Cytoplasm – Outer ectoplasm is clear, transparent, and refractile. Inner endoplasm is finely granular, having a ground glass appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are finger-like projections formed by sudden jerky movements of ectoplasm in one direction.
  • Nucleus is spherical 4-6 μm in size and contains central karyosome, surrounded by clear halo and anchored to the nuclear membrane by fine radiating fibrils, giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Ingested erythrocytes may also be present within the cytoplasm of E. histolytica trophozoites.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Entamoeba Coli: E. coli trophozoites are larger than E. histolytica, ranging from 20-50 micrometers in size. They have multiple nuclei (up to 8) with a small central karyosome and a coarse, irregularly granular cytoplasm. E. coli trophozoites often contain ingested bacteria, cell debris, or leukocytes.

Option C - Entamoeba Gingivalis: Trophozoites are 10 to 20 μm actively motile with multiple pseudopodia and have a single nucleus with a small eccentric karyosome, and contain engulfed epithelial cells or leukocytes.

Option D - Entamoeba Polecki: E. polecki trophozoites are similar in size to E. histolytica but have multiple nuclei (up to 16) with a small central karyosome and a coarsely granular cytoplasm. They may also contain ingested bacteria, yeast cells, or debris.

questions.text: Which is correct about the larval stage of Taenia solium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cysticercus Cellulosae:

  • The larval stage of Taenia solium, a parasitic tapeworm, is known as cysticercus cellulose, aka bladder worm, is responsible for causing cysticercosis.
  • In this condition, the larval cysts of the tapeworm can be found in various tissues of the body, including the muscles, brain, and subcutaneous tissues. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cysticercus Bovis: Cysticercus bovis is the larval stage of Taenia saginata responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

Option C - Chigger: Chigger is a 6-legged larval stage of trombiculid mite responsible for causing Scrub typhus/Chigger-borne disease.

Option D - None of the Above: Cysticercus cellulosae is the larval stage of Taenia solium.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species:

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax:

  • The invasion of red cells by merozoites requires specific glycoprotein receptors, i.e., Duffy blood group antigen, to invade red blood cells. Individuals who lack this antigen are generally resistant to P. vivax infection, while those who have it are susceptible to the parasite.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Drug-resistant falciparum is seen in India: Drug-resistant Plasmodium falciparum, the most virulent species of malaria, is indeed seen in India.

Option C - Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold, clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D - Relapse is seen in P. Ovale: Relapse is a unique characteristic of Plasmodium ovale and vivax infection. After the initial infection is treated, the parasite can remain dormant in the liver and cause relapses of malaria symptoms months or even years later.

questions.text: A 29-year-old middle school teacher presented to the OPD with lower abdominal pain, laterally radiating, and dysuria. In urine examination, eggs with terminal spines were seen. Computerized tomography (CT) scans revealed extensive calcifications of the urinary tract. A probable diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder was made on histopathological examination. Which of the following parasites lives in the bladder plexus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Schistosoma Hematobium:

Schistosoma Haematobium

Schistosoma Mansoni

Schistosoma Japonicum

Resides in pelvic vesical venous plexus.

Resides in Inferior mesenteric venous plexus draining sigmoid rectal region

Resides in Superior mesenteric venous plexus draining ilecocecal region
  • Hematuria
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma>> Transitional Cell Carcinoma of urinary bladder.

Swimmers Itch
  • Severe swimmer’s itch
  • Genital schistosomiasis
  • CNS schistosomiasis

Terminal spine

 

Lateral spine

Rudimentry Spine

Seen in urine sample

Seen in stool sample

Seen in stool sample

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

Option D - Fasciola Hepatica: It is a parasitic liver fluke that infects the liver and bile ducts, leading to bile duct obstruction, jaundice, and pain right upper quadrant pain. It has operculated eggs.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trichuris Trichiura:

  • Trichuris trichiura also known as whipworm, is a parasitic roundworm that infects the large intestine of humans. The characteristic symptoms of a Trichuris trichiura infection include abdominal pain, distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea (dysentery), tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation), and rectal prolapse (in severe cases).
  • The presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs in the stool examination is a key diagnostic feature of Trichuris trichiura infection and can be identified microscopically in the feces of infected individuals. These eggs are bile stained, and mucous plugs at both ends that are non-bile stained.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia Lamblia: Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes a diarrheal illness known as giardiasis. However, the characteristic symptom of giardiasis is watery diarrhea, not bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea.

Option C - Ascaris Lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large parasitic roundworm that primarily infects the small intestine and manifests as protein-energy malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, urticaria, angioneurotic edema and may cause mechanical obstruction. 

Option D - Ancylostoma Duodenale: Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans by penetrating the skin, usually through the feet. Hookworm infections can cause ground itch, creeping eruptions, respiratory symptoms like pneumonitis, and bronchitis, vomiting, and diarrhea. Eggs are oval or elliptical, colorless, not bile stained, and surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Entamoeba Histolytica:

  • Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that can cause intestinal infections, specifically amoebic dysentery.
  • One of the characteristic features of amoebic dysentery is the presence of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon. 
  • The trophozoites of E. histolytica damage the mucosa and submucosa but cannot damage the muscular as it is difficult to break. Thus, it starts breaking the submucosa on the sides, resulting in a flask-shaped ulcer.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not cause flask-shaped ulcers in the colon.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod–human transmission route?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Japanese Encephalitis:

  • Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which is transmitted through a bird-arthropod-human transmission route. The primary transmission cycle involves mosquito Culex as the arthropod vector and ardeid birds as the reservoir hosts. Mosquitoes acquire the virus by feeding on infected birds and then transmit it to humans through their bites. Humans are accidental hosts, and pigs are amplifiers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Malaria: Malaria is transmitted through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes that acquire the causative organism plasmodium by feeding on infected individual.

Option C - Plague: Plague is primarily transmitted through the bites of infected fleas that acquire the causative organism Yersinia by feeding on wild rodents.

Option D - Paragonimiasis: Paragonimiasis is a parasitic infection caused by lung flukes of the genus Paragonimus. It is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater crustaceans, such as crabs and crayfish.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab now presents with complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Paragonimus Westermani:

  • Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke that causes paragonimiasis, a parasitic infection characterized by chronic cough and rusty or bloody sputum containing eggs. The infection is commonly acquired by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater crustaceans, such as crabs and crayfish, which serve as second intermediate hosts for the parasite. The patient's history of travel to China and consumption of pickled crab aligns with the potential exposure to Paragonimus westermani.
  • Humans are the definitive hosts, and snails act as the first intermediate hosts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fasciola Buski: Fasciola buski is a trematode that causes a parasitic infection of the intestine characterized by diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. It is acquired by consuming contaminated water plants, such as watercress, which are the second intermediate hosts. Humans and sheep are the definitive hosts, and snails act as the first intermediate hosts.

Option B - Fasciola Hepatica: Fasciola hepatica is another trematode that causes a parasitic infection of the liver characterized by right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pain, and bile duct obstruction. It is also acquired by consuming contaminated water plants, such as watercress, which are the second intermediate hosts.

Option D - Schistosoma Japonicum: Schistosoma japonicum is a blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis characterized by intestinal mucosa hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and portal hypertension. It is acquired by penetration of the skin by cercariae released by snails, the intermediate host contaminating the freshwater sources.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under the surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus, which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same.

choices.text: Classic scabies have a lower mite burden than crusted scabies
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Male Parasite Burrows into the Epidermis:

  • The clinical presentation and image showing the causative organism Sarcoptes scabiei is characterized by a round body dorsally and a flattened body ventrally, covered with short bristles, and has two pairs of legs in front and two pairs behind are suggestive of scabies. Classic scabies typically manifest as an intensely pruritic eruption with a characteristic distribution. The sides and webs of the fingers, wrists, axillae, areolae, and genitalia are among the common sites of involvement.
  • Scabies is a parasitic infestation of the skin caused by the burrowing of female mites into the epidermis facilitated by the secretion of proteolytic enzymes that cause keratinocyte damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Life History has 4 Stages: The life cycle of Sarcoptes scabiei involves four stages: egg, larva, nymph, and adult.

Option B - Larvae have 4 Pairs of Legs: The larvae of Sarcoptes scabiei have four pairs of legs.

Option C - Classic Scabies have a Lower Mite Burden than Crusted Scabies: The mite burden in a patient with classic scabies is 10 to 15 mites, and for crusted scabies, the mite burden goes up to millions.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocyst of size 4 to 8 µm as shown below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cryptosporidium:

  • Coccidian parasites are responsible for causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual (HIV). Cryptosporidium is the most common among coccidian parasites to cause persistent diarrhea. The image showing an acid-fast oocyst round in shape confirms the causative parasite to be Cryptosporidium parvum. It is stained with modified acid-fast staining using 0.2%-1% of acid alcohol, showing a pinkish-red color.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts on modified acid-fast technique, stain red to reddish-orange, 8-12 μm in size, round, variably acid-fast, contains two sporocysts each bearing sporozoites.

Option C- Microsporum: Microsporum are associated with skin and hair dermatophytoses.

Option D - Cystoisospora: Cystoisospora, formerly known as Isospora, is another protozoan parasite that can cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. Oocyst of isospora are also acid-fast, but the size of the oocyst is large, i.e., 23-36 μm in size, and is oval in shape.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cysticercus cellulosae:

  • The given image of the CT scan of the brain shows multiple calcified cysts of cysticercus cellulosae in the brain parenchyma and a history of seizures is suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - T. saginata: Taenia saginata is another species of tapeworm that infects humans, but it causes a different condition known as intestinal taeniasis. Taeniasis occurs when a person ingests the larval stage (cysticercus bovis) of Taenia saginata found in undercooked beef.

Option C - Cysticercus bovis: Cysticercus bovis is the larval stage of Taenia saginata found in undercooked beef and responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

Option D - T. asiatica: Taenia saginata asiatica is another species of tapeworm that resembles Taenia saginata, and cysticerci are located in the liver.
